div.head: PROLOGUE TO THE RAGE.

lg.l: HOW narrow is the ſphere a modern Bays
Is doom'd to range, while he contrives his Plays;
Still urg'd by folly, Beings to explore,
Whom he and you ſo often ſaw before:
Precluded characters by their advance,
Whoſe minds could pierce thro' Nature with a glance,
And ſtill of right poſſeſs the moral Stage
With leſſons ſtudied in a diſtant age;
In this, our glaſs, you yet reflected find
The levities which leſſen human kind:
The lighter follies which the Town engage,
All that prevail in faſhion makes—the Rage;
Yes, all! though various be the motly forms,
That ſway by weak'ning, or compel in ſtorms:
That up to Fop evaporate the Lord;
Or down to Jockey ſink the Maid ador'd;
Confound diſtinctions, firm and frail perplex,
And make it difficult—to gueſs even ſex.
But is the Rage to levity confin'd?
Does no juſt paſſion ſway the general mind?
Lo! the rough Veteran, whom his Country's claim,
Rouſes to vindicate her injured name!
The Rage is Conqueſt which his boſom fires,
The foe yields! then—no! then his rage expires.
When in ſome dreadful conteſt on the wave
The gallant ſeaman finds a wat'ry grave,
E'er the laſt pulſe of ebbing life be o'er,
When the eye turns towards his native ſhore,
This thought may ev'n the parting pang aſſuage
That, there—Humanity is ſtill the Rage.
Our Author's Muſe follows with faſhion's gale,
Down a ſmooth river an amuſive ſail;
She dares no ſea where boiſterous paſſions ſway,
Or merely dips her wing, and haſtes away.
O may her airy toil your love engage,
And her new flight to pleaſe you be—The Rage.

div.head: EPILOGUE TO THE RAGE.

lg.l: WELL, Gentlefolks, again your moſt obedient;
That I'm the Epilogue is held expedient:
Our Bard, who for a youth well knows the Stage,
Thought as to ſpeaking, Women were "The Rage,"
And ſaid—"Good Mrs. Mattocks, pray, advance;
Females muſt now ſtep forward as in France."
My anſwer was—my dear, kind Sir, have pity,
"Pray ſpare the Ladies—Men ſecure our city.
"For arm'd by Parliament, to calm each fear,
"Huge corps of Common-Councilmen appear,
"Wards, Liveries, Deputies, en Militaire,
"Led by Lieutenant-Colonel—my Lord Mayor!
"Each man, (a ſight at which his Lady ſwoons,)
"Belt, ſabre, helmet, ſpurs, and pantaloons!
"Dear Chuck"—ſays Spouſe—"pray ſit at home, do yielde,
"Conſider, Love, your age; you grow unwieldy;
"Good twenty ſtone, Dear, cannot play about,
"Beſides thoſe cold Jack Boots hurt Lovey's Gout."
"Gout! vulgar nonſenſe Voman—Gout! Gad's curſe,
"Heavy! why I'm a private of Light Horſe—
"Dreſs! wheel! charge!—Could I on Horſeback get
"I or my horſe would do ſome miſchief yet.'
Thus, meaning no offence, in language faint,
The City Rage for ſoldiering we paint.
But ſure no ſons of Briton, wiſh repreſt
That zeal which leads one man to ſerve the reſt;
Which ſtrives due right and order to maintain,
Againſt a Chaos that would come again.
Long may ſuch Rage inſpire the Engliſh mind!
In neighbouring Climes a different "Rage" we find;
Poor Jean François who ſhouts for Liberté
Finds Slavery ſtill the Order of the Day!
"Ma foi! he cries—no people bleſt as we
They force me out to fight to make me free,
Den! vif! alert!—begar we muſt not tarry,
My Vife, for common good, oblige to marry:
She labour for the State, tant mieux pour elle,
She forget me—I her—c'eſt Bagatelle!
Allons au Guerre! L'eau de vie baniſh ſorrow,
Victoire to-day—La Guillotine to-morrow!"
Engliſh Tom Blunt, a dealer in ſmall wares,
Who knows a bit what's paſſing above ſtairs.
Cries—"Why in that there change of wives ſo faſt
"I think a good one mayhap may come at laſt,
"But in that gulleting machine, d'ye ſee,
"I've no idea how it makes one free:
"For my part now, whatever may be ſaid,
"I'm for a little meat, and ſafe warm bed,
"I does not reliſh freedom—when one's dead;
"So once for all my means and reſolution
"Go, to ſtand by the good old Conſtitution."
Such and ſo different reign with ſovereign power,
The various "Rages" of the preſent hour.
I wiſh, in truth I wiſh in very ſpight,
Your Rage may be, to ſee us many a night.

div.head: THE RAGE: A COMEDY.
ACT I.
SCENE I.—DARNLEY'S Garden, and view of his ſmall Villa.
div.stage: Enter DARNLEY and Sir GEORGE GAUNTLET.

sp.speaker: SIR GEORGE.
sp.p: AND ſo, Darnley, you prefer this ſolitary life, to all the joys of London—to be ſure you've a nice ſnug Villa, and a charming wife here—but its dull—the ſcene tires—it wants variety, Harry.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No, Sir George.—Since I retir'd to this peaceful ſpot, I have not had a wiſh beyond it: I've been ſo happy in that humble cottage, that when I'm doom'd to leave it, the world will be a waſte, and life not have a charm!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
How you are alter'd, Darnley? When we were brother officers you were the greateſt rake in the regiment; but from the
time we were quarter'd at Worceſter, where you firſt beheld Miſs Dormer—

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I ſaw the folly of my former life; I own'd the power of her ſuperior charms, and leaving a buſy and tumultuous world, retir'd with her to this ſequeſter'd ſcene—'tis now three years ſince I married.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: And from that time to this, have you liv'd in this out-of-the-way place?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Yes: and till you yeſterday honour'd me with a viſit, I have not ſeen a friend within my doors—but isn't it a happy life, Sir George? Our affections have room to ſhoot—care and diſtruſt are baniſh'd from our cottage, and with ſuch a woman as Mrs. Darnley to converſe with, what is the world to me? I can defy and ſcorn its malice.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: She's an angelic creature indeed, Darnley: and at Worceſter, I had myſelf nearly fallen a victim to her charms; but about your future life—do you mean to live for ever in theſe woods and meadows?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No—would to heaven I could!—I fear I muſt forego my preſent calm, and mix in active life again: When I married, I ſold my commiſſion, you remember, to purchaſe this ſmall farm—Mrs. Darnley's portion was but a trifle, and an encreaſing family has ſo enlarg'd my expences, that unleſs I return to the army—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Ah—you want to be raking again?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
No—I want to ſecure an independence for my family—I want to ſee my children affluent, and to attain this, I have once more applied to my uncle Sir Paul Perpetual,
who was ſo offended at my ſelling out, that he has ever ſince abandon'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: What—does the old beau ſtill perſevere in his reſentment?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: His anger has encreas'd; for he writes me word; he intends marrying Lady Sarah Savage, on purpoſe to have heirs more worthy his eſtate:—Oh! my friend:—'tis hard, that fortune ſhould beſtow ſuch treaſures, and then compel me to deſert them?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: So it is: but now I think on't, this Lady Sarah Savage and her brother are my intimate friends; and as you are their neighbours, I'll introduce you and Mrs. Darnley to their notice—When are they expected from town?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: To day.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Then we'll pay them a viſit: Lady Sarah Savage ſhall interfere with your uncle, and if that fails, her brother can eaſily enſure your promotion in the army—but ſee; here's Mrs. Darnley?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Look at her, Sir George—do you, can you blame me?—who would not act as I have done?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I would by heav'ns!—I'd live with her in a hermitage!—die with her on a pilgrimage!—I'd—ſdeath: if I don't mind, I ſhall diſcover all.

sp.speaker: Darnley advancing to her.
sp.p: Maria!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Oh Harry!—I have been looking for you every where—I declare you're grown quite a truant—Before your friend came, you
us'd to walk with me over the farm: or ride with me to ſee our children; or ſit and read to me under our favourite Beach Tree—but now—Sir George!—I beg your pardon—I didn't ſee you before.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: My friend is all kindneſs, Maria; he has promis'd to introduce me to the honourable Mr. Savage:

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: What:—take you to Savage houſe!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Ay—why not:—you ſhall go with me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: No—let me ſtay here—I am not weary of my preſent life.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Nor I—but 'tis a great connexion: and though not abſolutely diſtreſs'd, I would improve my fortune—I would ſee you and my children have every comfort.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: We have, while you are with us—conſider we have never liv'd a day apart, and if they lure you into faſhionable ſcenes, you'll be corrupted, Harry—you'll deſpiſe the humble roof you once rever'd, and I perhaps ſhall be forgotten and neglected.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Never!—I cannot bear the ſuppoſition; and while we have hearts to endure, and hands to labour, there is ſufficient for our cottage!—I will not go—My friend, who ſees my motive, I'm ſure, will not condemn me.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: No—always obey the Ladies; but Darnley, I ſee our horſes—you recollect we were to ride to ſee your children: ſo, Madam, I have the ſuperlative honour—

div.stage: Enter CLARA SEDLEY—a baſket of flowers is hanging on her arm, and ſhe is eating an apple.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: What, Clara!—been picking flowers my angel!—well!—I thought they had all died—all died from envy egad! ha! ha!—excuſe me—I never laugh but at my own wit.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Do you? then you laugh very ſeldom, I believe.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: No—very often: for I take the joke though nobody elſe does, ha! ha!—come Darnley—adieu Ladies—I'll not run away with him!—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What a coxcomb it is!—and if he wasn't a duelliſt into the bargain, I'd tell Mr. Darnley all my ſuſpicions—that I would—but he's ſo fond of fighting, that I heard him ſay, he once ſent a man a challenge for wafering a letter inſtead of ſealing it.—I wiſh he was gone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Indeed ſo do I, couſin—Mr. Darnley is ſo chang'd ſince he arriv'd—his ideas ſo enlarg'd—he talks of viſiting at Savage Houſe, of improving his fortune.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Fortune!—ay: and this morning he gave me his note for two hundred pounds, begging me to get one of my guardians to lend money upon it—his excuſe was that his expences exceeded his income, and by his uncle's marriage with Lady Sarah Savage, all his expectations were ruined—Now, my life on't, this is all Sir George's doings—He has ſtole into our cottage like the Arch-fiend into paradiſe, and I won't eat another apple while he ſtays!
sp.stage: (Throws away the apple ſhe is eating.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Is Darnley then diſtreſſed?—Oh Clara!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Don't be unhappy—I ſhall apply to both my guardians; Sir Paul and Mr. Fluſh, they are now at Bath, and one way or other the Villa ſhall flouriſh ſtill—Lord! I ſhall have plenty of money when I come of age, and I'll throw it all into the ſcale, and come and plant, ſow, and reap with you and your huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: What give up the gaieties of London, couſin?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: London! ay: I hate it—I once paſs'd a month there, but they hurried me ſo from ſight to ſight, that in the buſtle all places appear'd alike—I ſaw no difference—And, if you'll believe me, one morning after ſeeing Weſtminſter Hall in term time, they took me inſide Bedlam; and ſo confus'd was I, that I didn't know the lawyers and their clients, from the keepers and their patients.
"Trompite, trompite tra!"

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Who can this be?
"Tra—tra—tra!"

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Bleſs us!—What animal's this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: He has miſtaken his way, I ſuppoſe—Sir— (Signor don't regard her.) I beg pardon, Sir—but perhaps you don't know that this garden—

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: "Beviamo tutta trè!"—ah, ha!— les Demoiſelles!—Ladies, à votre ſervice.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: I and the Honourable Miſter Savage arrive laſt night—ce Matin I take a my little valk—ſee your ſmall Chateau, and am ſo enchanté w •• h the ſpectàcle that—me voici!—I honour you with my firſt viſit—eh bien!—vat is your names?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Our names!—rather we ſhould aſk yours.

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Mine!—Diable!—do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No—how ſhould we?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Vat! not know I am Signor Cygnet— de firſt Violin in Europe! de beſt compoſer in de whole world!—de huſband of Signora Cygnet —de great ſinger at de opera—de profeſſional—de Abbey—de—Marbleu!—and am I not myſelf?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No—I don't think you are yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: And ſo, Sir, you are on a viſit at Mr. Savage's?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Oui—in my vay to Bath I condeſcend to paſs a few days there—Lady Sarah Savage, ſhe love muſic, or pretend to love— vich is de ſame ting you know—they entertain me comme çâ—give me good dinners, and take ticketts for mine and my vife's concert—mais there be two tings I don't like.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And what are they, Sir?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Vy Miſter Savage, he give me cold ſuppers and ſleep in the beſt bed himſelf—Now, begar!—I vill have hot ſuppers and de beſt bed, or elſe I take a my fiddle and promenez—"Malbrouk s'en va, &c." (Singing.)—De grand Duke—O! de grand Duke—he never uſe me thus—never—jamais!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: The Grand Duke!

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Oui—ven I was at Florence how you tink he treat me? accoutez—he quarrel with all his Miniſters—all but one!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And who was that one?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Me!—me he ſhake by the hand and go to my vife's benefit toût le même—de ſame as ever!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Upon my word, muſic ſeems ſo important a ſcience, that I think you had better let your little boy have ſome leſſons—it is neceſſary for his education—isn't it, Signor?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Neceſſaire!—ma foi: 'tis de only education now-a-days—never mind vat you call Latin and Greek—put de fiddle in his little hand and let him ſcrape away! den he vill be great man—like me: and call for hot ſupper and beſt bed verever he go!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: What! ſhall I give up making a parſon of him, Clary?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Parſon!—pif!—vat is de parſon to de muſician?—he ride his old white horſe—preach away at four or five churches, and vat he get?—forty pounds a year—Eh bien! I and my vife ride in vis-a-vis—ſing only ven we like, and make five thouſand a year—ah ha! voila la difference!—Parſon!—begar! de blind fidler get more money!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: More ſhame for the country then, where foreign arrogance is ſo rewarded, and gentlemanly merit ſo inſulted—come Clara—

sp.speaker: Sir George
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, Mrs. Darnley; but I and your huſband have juſt been preſent at an accident, that—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: An accident, ſir!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Yes: Lady Sarah Savage, who is one of thoſe ladies call'd female phaetoneers, was driving four in hand acroſs the heath; the horſes took fright, and ran away with her, when Darnley, with more gallantry than prudence, rode a-head of the unruly animals, and ſtopt them on the edge of a precipice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Heaven be prais'd!—and where is the lady, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: My friend is conducting her to the villa, where he begs you'll inſtantly join them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: By all means—come—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Signor, won't you aſſiſt your friend?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Non—I am muſician, not phyſician, and my head is ſo full of de tune.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: So full of de vapour, he means—like the inſide of his own violin—come couſin—now isn't it a pity, that while we have butterflies and bullfinches in the garden, we ſhould be tormented with coxcombs and fiddlers—inſects, adieu

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Signor, I rejoice to ſee you; you have often aſſiſted me in my amours, and I now want your aid more than ever.

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Eh bien!—my vife has a concert at Bath next week.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Has ſhe! then I'll give a dinner to ſome Somerſetſhire bumpkins, and force off
a ſcore or two of tickets—You ſaw the lady I firſt ſpoke to—ſhe has won my heart, and I have won her huſband's.

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Dat is good—den if you make de diſcord between them—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Ay, Sgnior: if I excite jealouſy! and this accident has ſprung the mine—Lady Sarah Savage is already half in love with Darnley—She has invited him to Savage houſe, and if he takes Mrs. Darnley along with him—

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Dey will be both out of tune for ever—ah ha! I go to Mr. Savage, touteſuite.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Do—and increaſe Lady Sarah's love for Darnley—aſſiſt in all my ſchemes; triumph I muſt, and will; for I offer'd Mrs. Darnley my hand long before this huſband won her heart.

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: I will be firſt fiddle reſt aſſurè—tenez; I vill compoſe two duettos—one between Lady Sarah Savage and de huſband—de other between you and de vife—allòns. You no conceive the power of muſic, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I do, Signor—for as Shakeſpeare ſays: There's nought ſo ſtockiſh, hard and full of rage, but muſic for a time does change its nature.

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Shakeſpeare! vat is dat Shakeſpeare? He never compoſe a ſingle tune, and dough at preſent he make a little noiſe, begar, you'll ſoon find de fiddle and de bravura vill lay him on de ſhelf—now-a-days, ſound always get de better of ſenſe, mon ami—Ah ha! venez! you no forget my vife's benefit.

div.head: SCENE II.—A Room inſide Mr. DARNLEY'S Villa, Prints, Books, Fowling Pieces, Fiſhing Tackle, &c.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Well Clara: if Lady Sarah Savage be a picture of town-bred women of faſhion, let me remain a plain ſimple ruſtic all my life—Did you ever ſee any thing ſo confident—ſo maſculine—her brother too! "What you call impudence," ſays he, "we call eaſe."

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ay: they're a precious pair; and yet in London they are both the Rage!—quite at the top of the beau monde—But, couſin, they've order'd their carriages, and inſiſt on our going to Savage houſe—Mercy on us! what's to become of two lambs amongſt ſuch a parcel of wolves?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: This is Sir George's ſcheme: to delude Mr. Darnley from this tranquil ſpot into faſhionable life, is the firſt ſtep towards affecting his baſe deſigns—He told Mr. Savage about your fortune too—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I know it: and the vulgar man made downright love to me directly;—'faith-Coz. I believe Sir George wants to get me married, and you unmarried.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah Savage without.)
sp.p: Bring round the Phaeton, and d'ye hear—don't tighten the curbs—I'll whip and gallop them every inch of the road.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
"She'll whip and gallop them!" there now!—this is one of the modern breed of
fine ladies, who, inſtead of being feminine and tender, have the Rage for confidence and boldneſs—Look at her dreſs—ſhe's more like a man than a woman, and her language is as maſculinè as her manners.

div.stage: Enter Lady SARAH SAVAGE dreſſed in a great coat, with a number of capes; a plain round beaver hat; a fur tippet and ſaſh. Boot ſhoes, a whip in her hand, and a riding habit, under great coal; two grooms enter with her.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: John, exerciſe the pointers, and the hounds—I ſhall ſhoot to-morrow, and hunt the next day.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Any thing elſe, madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: No—nothing—Oh yes: call at the taylor's and enquire for my fencing jacket—tell him I broke two foils in my laſt rencontre, and aſk him if any body ought to make aſſaults in a gown and petticoat?—Ah! my little dears—here (Seeing Mrs. Darnley and Clara, ſhe makes them pull off her great coat, which the groom takes.) Well! and how do ye do? Oh William!—tell the recruiting ſerjeant I muſt learn the new military manoeuvres, and bid him bring the largeſt fuſil in the regiment—there—go along—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: I hope you have recover'd your fright, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Recover'd!—heh!—why, where's my deliverer!—my dear charming Mr. Darnley?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
He is certainly the moſt divine engaging creature—I mean to take him home
with me, and the Phaeton is waiting—ſo call him, child— (to Clara.) call him directly.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Call:—whom, madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Darnley, to be ſure; what does the girl ſtare at?—did ſhe never ſee a perſon of quality before.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Never—its the firſt time, ma'am; and if this is the ſpecimen, I hope it will be the laſt:—I'll call Mr. Darnley.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: I wiſh I was like you, my dear—I wiſh I was married—its ſo comfortable—ſo convenient—heigho!—I ſhall be ſo glad when old Sir Paul is my ſtalking horſe—my huſband I mean—ſhan't you, Mrs.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Excuſe me, madam: when I reflect, that Sir Paul is Mr. Darnley's uncle, and by your union he is deprived of all his future fortune, you cannot blame me, if —

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Deprive my dear Darnley of his fortune!—ſo it does—well!—that's vaſtly droll!—but then it makes mine, which is the ſame thing you know—See!—here's my bear of a brother!—you've no idea what low, vulgar company he keeps?—nothing but Buffoons, Bow-ſtreet Officers, and Boxers!—and only conceive, my dear, me and my friends mixing in ſuch horrid ſociety.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Surely Mr. Savage cannot wiſh—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
He does, ma'am: and only conceive I ſay my intimate acquaintance—people of the firſt conſequence—ſuch as Signor Cygnet, the huſband of the fine Soprano—Monſieur Puppitini, the inventor of the dear Fantoccini, and Count Spavin the greateſt of Horſe Doctors—only imagine ſuch pick'd company
as this, mixing with my brother's low-liv'd wretched crew.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Indeed, ma'am, people of rank ought to ſet a better example.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: So Savage—ſiſter I mean—I loſt ten pounds by your ſilly accident—The moment I ſaw the horſes off, I ſaid to my friends around me, ten pounds to five, the driver gets a tumble—"done!"—"it's a bett" ſays I—away flew the racers,—ſnap went the reins—five to four in my ſavour!—when plague on't! the Squire rode acroſs, ſtopt the carriage—you ſav'd your neck, and I—loſt my wager.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: You brute: did you ever hear your brother, Lord Savage, talk in this manner?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: My brother!—pough!—he's a gentleman to be ſure—proud, independent, and all in the grandee ſtyle—but I!—I'm not like him—I'm a man of faſhion—I'm not a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: No—that you are not upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: I am the hero of my ſociety—he is the ſlave of his—he keeps high company, ma'am (To Mrs. Darnley,) lives with judges, generals, and admirals—but does he ever encourage the arts and ſciences? does he ever ſhake hands with men of genius? ſuch as peace officers, tennis play'rs, and boxers—no, no—that was left for me.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Yes: and though born to wealth and titles, there you ſtand, that have been ſix times bottle holder at a boxing match!—vulgar ſcience!—I hope Sir Paul don't underſtand it.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: No—not now—but if he makes you his wife, it may be neceſſary he ſhould, learn,— I ſay, ma'am, that was a ſtraight one—wasn't it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Indeed I don't know, ſir; —Wou'd Mr. Darnley were here!—I am unequal to their ſociety; but from the little I have learnt, I think one hour of domeſtic life worth all this new unintelligible ſcene.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Hark'ye: (to Lady Sarah,) here's a letter from the old beau, Sir Paul—he is coming to Bath, and can only ſtay one day with us, in his way; but as people of quality are not always people of quantity you know, he ſhan't ſtir, till the marriage is effected—mum!—I'll keep him cloſe—

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Ha! ſquire!—come Mrs. Darnley; (takes her by the hand.) I'll drive you and your pretty couſin—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Sir, I am unus'd to viſiting; unfit—

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Nonſenſe!—I never take an excuſe; when I aſk people to my houſe, I make them go when I like—ſtay while I like, and behave as I like—ſo come along—ſquire mind you don't ſnap the reins; and d'ye hear; as my ſiſter is rather lame—only juſt recover'd from the gout—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: The gout!—how dare you, ſir?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
What!—do you deny it?—do you diſown having been our'd by a quack doctor, and returning him thanks in all the papers? Lady Sarah Savage informs Dr. Panacea, that his alagaronic antiſpaſmodonic tincture, has entirely remov'd the gout from the extremities,
and ſhe now hunts, ſhoots, eats and drinks more freely than ever!—now isn't it a ſhame, ma'am? between them, they plunder both the patient and the phyſician.—The quack cheats the doctor of his fee, and the woman robs the man of his gout.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Darnley!—I am ſo glad you're going to Savage houſe—'twill be ſuch a relief—come—I'll appoint you my rural Cicisbeo—my guardian ſhepherd—you ſav'd my life, and I won't let you die for me, I am determin'd!

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I.—The Honourable Mr. SAVAGE'S Park and Garden—a Canal with a Veſſel on it—a Bridge—a Temple ſurrounded with Weeping Willows—at the Wing a Portico and Steps leading to the Houſe.
div.stage: Enter DARNLEY and Sir GEORGE GAUNTLET from the Portico.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Why now indeed you are an alter'd man?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I am—I am—the wine—the ſcene —the company—has ſo tranſported me, that I begin to think I'm not quite ſober, Sir George— I do indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: No wonder at it—you've led the life of a recluſe and every new ſcene dazzles you —you are like a nun eſcap'd from a convent.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No—more like a Friar in one—at leaſt if I may judge by my eating and drinking— But my friend—this is a glorious place, and I begin to think I've liv'd too long out of the world—coop'd up in a cottage—buried in a farm—What did I know of life and all its pleaſures?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Ay: what indeed?—in town—and Savage-houſe is the ſame thing you ſee; for they always bring London into the country with them —but Lady Sarah, Darnley—I ſaw you at dinner;—ſhe gave you ſuch affectionate looks.—

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Fie! fie Sir George—you forget— I am a married man.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: A married man!—what then!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Why then I love my wife—I do— I tenderly love her—and when I chuſe to play the fool, let me expoſe myſelf, but not wound her for heaven's ſake!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Nonſenſe!—you don't know Lady Sarah—ſhe is one of thoſe confident females, who won't let a man eſcape—who mark you for their prey—lure you into their talons; and, if you don't yield, will ſo claw you.—

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: What! make me love her whether I will or not?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Certainly: but conſider the advantages of her friendſhip: firſt ſhe can get you promotion in the army; ſecondly, by gaining an aſcendancy over her, you may prevent her marrying your uncle; and thirdly, you can provide for your family without injuring your honour—there!—there's an opportunity!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: That's true; and if I thought— hark'ye; as we're alone, and you're my beſt of friends—I've got a letter from her! the Signor brought it me—here! (taking out a letter.)—She appoints me to meet her in her dreſſing-room.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Bravo, Signor!— (aſide)—let's read. — (Reads the Letter.)— Lady Sarah Savage, having ſomething particular to communicate to Mr. Darnley, begs to ſee him in her dreſſing-room in an hour's time.—Go by all means,—go, I inſiſt.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Why, if I can perſuade her not to marry Sir Paul, or even get her to interfere with him —I'll go!—I'm fix'd—I'll write to her this inſtant. He that eſſays no danger gains no praiſe!

div.stage: Enter the Honourable Mr. SAVAGE haſtily.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Joy! joy my lads! Sir Paul is arrived! and how do you think the old boy introduced himſelf to my porter?—"Tell your maſter, ſays he, a young gentleman deſires to ſee him."

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Young gentleman!—that's excellent—he's at leaſt ſeventy-two.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: No, you wrong him; he's only ſeventy—Sir Paul Perpetual—Old P. I mean; for that's his nick name you know—has been the ancient beau of the age theſe thirty years, and as his great grief is, that he never had a ſon, he wants my conſent to marry my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: And do you mean to conſent, ſir?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Certainly—I ſay (aſide to Sir George) —I want his fortune to repair my own, and therefore he ſhan't leave the houſe till the marriage is effected—you know my way.—I've given the hint to the ſervants.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir here's the young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Squire, take my place at the table— puſh the wine about, and tell the jovial crew to prepare for quizzing—quizzing you rogue!— go (Darnley exit)—the licenſe is in my pocket, a parſon's in the houſe, and if we can but confuſe the young gentleman, we'll marry him in a joke, and afterwards take his fortune in earneſt.

div.stage: Enter SIR PAUL PERPETUAL, in a riding dreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: "Be lively, briſk and jolly!—lively, briſk and jolly!" (ſinging.) Ah, my boys!—here I am—as young and hearty—but I can't ſtay; I muſt be at Bath to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: At Bath!—what to drink the waters? to renovate before marriage, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No—upon my ſoul there's no occaſion—though, at preſent, perhaps a little phyſical advice wouldn't be much amiſs: for between ourſelves, I've juſt cut a tooth, and ſuffer'd moſt violently from the hooping cough! (They laugh) —Why what do you laugh at?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Nothing—nothing—only we wonder'd how ſuch a chicken as you could ſtruggle againſt a pair of ſuch mortal diſorders!—but, ſeriouſly—what takes you to Bath?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Such an event? I have trac'd a ſon; a boy above twenty years of age! that's my firſt reaſon—my ſecond is—to ſee my grandfather.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Your grandfather!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hark'ye—he ſhall make ſettlements on my firſt four children.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Pray, Sir Paul—I beg your pardon though—what age may your grandfather be?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Two hundred, if he's an hour! heh? an't I right, old P.?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Old P.! there it is now!—here I ſtand, that walk as much as any man—that ride as much as any man—that am every night at a concert, an opera, or a club—that ſing, dance, game or intrigue! and what's more, that have done all this for ſixty years!—and yet to be call'd
old P!—they ſaid I never was a father—but I ſhall ſoon prove the great and glorious fact.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Ay! how will you prove it?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: How! why you've all heard of my little Nelly—poor girl! ſhe was jealous, and ſhe left me to marry a tradeſman—a clerk at a lottery office, and three months after we parted ſhe was deliver'd of a boy—a fine boy! as like me as one Cupid is to another—a year after her marriage, ſhe died, and I can hear nothing of her huſband; but let him ſay what he will, I'll ſwear the boy was mine; I'll ſwear it, becauſe I'm convinc'd I'm father to more children than one, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Very likely; but where did you learn all this?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: From Nelly's ſiſter; a month ago I accidentally met her at Tunbridge; ſhe had neither ſeen nor heard of the huſband ſince her ſiſter's death, but ſhe remember'd the child went by his mother's name! its mine!—I'm ſure its mine! and (they laugh again.) I tell you what—you'd better be careful; for when you and other young ſprigs of faſhion ſmile at me, jeer me, and call me the infirm old P.!—'gad! you little think you dogs, you are laughing at your own father perhaps! however, I've trac'd my boy to Bath, and whoever diſcovers him ſhall have the too beſt racers in my ſtud.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: What fidget and fizgig? then I'll ſeek for young P. myſelf—I'll find him—I'll— but hold—hold— (Stopping Sir Paul who is going) don't go yet—your nephew's in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
What Darnley?—zounds! then I won't ſtay a moment—no—not even to ſee my dear Lady Sarah, who I'll marry if its only to
diſappoint that rural reprobate—that—I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: No—you're not—I'll tell you a ſecret; you ſhall ſtay a week with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: A week!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Ay: I've my reaſons—ſo don't think of ſtirring; for your horſes are turn'd out to graſs—your ſaddles and bridles ſnug in a hiding place, and all the gates double bar'd, inſide and out.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What the devil! make a priſoner of me?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Nonſenſe!—I only foreſtall your wiſhes:—I'm ſure you want ſome ſoft diſcourſes with my ſiſter, and don't I know what my viſitors like better than they do themſelves? don't I know you like getting drunk?—ſo come; come in and drink!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I don't—I hate drinking; and death and fire! haven't I told you I want to find my ſon—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Humour him; humour him, Sir Paul; or he'll refuſe you his ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Ay: give conſent, or elſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Or elſe I loſe my wife I ſuppoſe; when I'm in the country, don't I like always to live quiet, and keep early hours, and would you lock me in a houſe where you never ſee the ſun? where you go to bed juſt before it riſes, and get up the moment after it ſets?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Will you give up the marriage, and let Darnley have his wiſh?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No—I'll die firſt—I'll—

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Then will you join the jolly crew and prove—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: That you have as much health, youth, and ſpirits—

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: As any choice ſpirit—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Or young gentleman—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: In the whole world!—I'm rous'd! I'm fir'd! and to ſhew I'm ſeaſon'd! true Engliſh heart of Oak!—allôns!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: "Bring the flaſk! the muſic—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: "Joy ſhall quickly find us—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: "Let us dance and laugh and ſing, and drive old care behind us!"

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Can this be the manſion of elegance and taſte? I meet with nothing but rudeneſs and neglect!—I wiſh I could find Mr. Darnley!—I dare ſay, by this time, he is ſicken'd of the ſcene, and anxious as myſelf, to ſee his home again.

div.stage: Enter DARNLEY from the Portico, half drunk, with Lady Sarah Savage's letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Fill away my boys!—fill!—fill!—while I like a faithful gallant!—gallant! hold, hold, friend Darnley. This letter is to benefit your intereſt, not ſacrifice your honour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Heavens!—what do I ſee? Mr. Darnley!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Yes:—you do; you ſee Mr. Darnley.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Why?—what's the matter with you!—what's that letter?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: This letter?—this is a love letter, my angel,—ha!—why it is!—it is my wife!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Yes: that wife who in the hour of diſſipation you forget—can I believe it?—in a little hour can all our paſt attachment—but why am I alarmed?—Faſhion may dupe the wicked and the weak, but virtue ſuch as his muſt ſcorn its empty power.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Forget!—no never!—and now I look at you—I think I ought to be maſſacred for having even for a moment neglected you—Oh Maria!—I have ſuch news for you—Lady Sarah has been ſo kind—ſhe has promiſed to promote me—to befriend you—and in ſhort ſhe has taken a liking to the whole family.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: And why, Harry?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Why! ay: there's the rub! but don't be jealous, Maria—I entreat you, don't be jealous!—for by heaven, I love you!—I do ſo tenderly that if it were not for my promiſe, I could find in my heart to return home directly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnly.
sp.p: Do; let us begone—the place diſtracts me: and I fear this high company will corrupt you.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: High company!—hang it:—if that's all you're afraid of, there's not much danger in this houſe I fancy—but my letter—my word to Sir George—and conſider our intereſt, Maria.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Oh no—conſult our happineſs my love; and ſurely there is none in this tumultuous ſcene—we left all joy behind us, in our children and our cottage, Harry; and there alone we ſhall recover it—come.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
She's right—the pretty prattler has reaſon on her ſide and who can diſobey— (looks
without,) ha!—Sir George and Lady Sarah in cloſe converſation!—they beckon me!—again!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Why do you pauſe?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I'm in for it—the die is caſt!—Maria!—excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: How! will you leave me, Mr. Darnley?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: What can I do?—'tis but for a ſhort time.—
You muſt not.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Nay: only for an hour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.stage: (Letting him go and taking out her handkerchief.)
sp.p: —This is the firſt time you ever us'd me thus.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: So it is—now what a pretty ſcoundrel I am!—and this is faſhionable life is it?—Oh fool! fool! to quit ſubſtantial peace for artificial pleaſure!—don't weep, Maria—I go for our mutual advantage—I go to make our children happy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Then ſtay with their mother—they never wiſh'd that we ſhould part.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Nor will we—we've liv'd ſo long and happily together, that I would rather loſe the little we have left, than hurt your quiet.— (Enter Sir George Gauntlet.) Sir George ſtay with her—I'll ſee Lady Sarah, entreat her forgiveneſs, and return inſtantly; for, oh my friend!—my heart drops blood for every tear ſhe ſheds.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
P'ſha!—remember your intereſt—Lady Sarah will ſoon reconcile your ſcruples, and leave me to compoſe Mrs. Darnley—nay: take your opportunity—you muſt keep the appointment—I inſiſt—ſo begone!— (Darnley exit.) What a fuſs here is about a man's leaving his
wife for an hour, when ſo many worthy couple would be happy to part for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Sir George, tell me, where is he gone? tell me, that I may fly and overtake him!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Why! can't you gueſs?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: No, indeed, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Not that he is gone to Lady Sarah to keep an aſſignation with her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: An aſſignation.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: In her dreſſing-room! at this very hour—the gay ſcene has ſo alter'd him, that you ſee he has left you to keep the appointment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: I'll not believe it!—he is above ſuch baſeneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Won't you?—then I'll prove it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: I defy you!—he knows the value of my heart too well to trifle with it; and I've known his ſo long, that I'll not venture to ſuſpect it—no—though his friend defames it.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Nay then—you remember his hand-writing—here is his anſwer to the lady's letter—read.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Ha!—it is too plain—I am deceiv'd—deſerted.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I was the bearer of that letter, and preſerv'd it merely to ſhew it you, I thought it the duty of a friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
And from the ſame duty, you advis'd him to write it.—Oh! I have known you long, Sir George—you are one of thoſe who find no happineſs but in marring that of others—who ſeduce the affections of the huſband, the better to betray the honour of the wife! and when you've ſpoilt all ſocial and domeſtic peace, the
friend you laugh at, and the woman ſcorn!—I know you well!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: My dear ma'am, how you miſtake!—I meant to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Sir—there is but one way—leave me—nay, I inſiſt—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I ſhall obey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: I muſt have ſtronger proof before I am convinc'd, and then obſerve, Sir George, if his truth weakens, I'll add ſtrength to mine! my conſtancy and honour ſhall be ſo exemplary, that I will ſhame him from his follies! make him repent: and when reclaim'd, be proud to ſay he is my own again!

div.head: SCENE II.—An elegant Apartment leading to Lady SARAH'S Dreſſing-Room—the Door in the Flat.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Yes: yes: its all over the Houſe—Sir George makes no ſecret of the aſſignation, and I've no doubt but Darnley is now in that room waiting for Lady Sarah Savage—ſhe can't come at preſent—the ſervant ſays, ſhe's gone to the ſtables to ſee the beaſts unharneſs'd—faith! if ſhe'd go to her brother's party ſhe'd ſee that buſineſs already done!—however I'll prevent Darnley's expoſing himſelf, and as he is certainly conceal'd in that room, I'll talk to him.—Dear!—here's my guardian again!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: So far, I'm ſafe, my dear girl; you don't know what your poor guardian has ſuffer'd in this high—no—this low-lif'd houſe!—they forc'd me into a room full of buffoons, boxers, and blacklegs—made me drink a bowl of punch, and I'd as ſoon drink ſo much poiſon—then winking and nodding they began whiſpering pretty loudly—"ſmoke the old prig!—damme, quiz him!"

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Quiz him!—what's that, Guardy?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, with our young men of quality, quizzing is a ſubſtitute for wit, my dear; ſo one man challeng'd me to play on the violin, and when I roſe to move my elbows, another whip'd the chair from under me; a ſecond put hot coals into my pocket, ſo when I felt for my hankerchief, I burnt my fingers; a third tried to cut off my tail, but that aſſaſſin I purſued, when unluckily in running after him, they had tied a ſtring acroſs the ſtairs, and I pitch'd headforemoſt into a barrel of water, they had placed for the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Indeed, its quite terrible, Gaurdy.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Then they ſhew'd me a licenſe; brought me a fat parſon, and ſaid, if I'd inſtantly be married, they'd let me go to find my ſon—if not, I ſhould be lock'd in, and have plenty of it—now here's hoſpitality!—but they've overſhot the mark; and if I get out of their doors, I'll not only break off the match, but promiſe to befriend Darnley.—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
What! diſappoint Lady Sarah, and relieve my poor diſtreſſed friend—then I'll get you out
of the houſe—I will, if I'm quizz'd to death for it—You ſee that door—if he meets Darnley, he'll at leaſt interrupt the aſſignation.—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Secure my eſcape—only get me out of this den of ſavages, and, if I don't befriend Darnley, may I never live to ſee old age. Where does that door lead to?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I fancy to Lady Sarah's dreſſing room; for it is full of half boots, horſe great coats, military ſaſhes, helmet caps, and amazonian jackets! and this is your only way to eſcape—enter that room.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Put on one of Lady Sarah Savage's great coats, tie one of her ſaſhes round your waiſt—throw a fur tippet about your neck, and with a whip in your hand, and her driving hat on your head—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I underſtand—the ſervants will take me for their miſtreſs, and open the gates; Oh! you dear girl! (kiſſes her.)—I'll about it inſtantly— (opens the door in flat.) I ſay, Clara, the hounds below are unkennel'd; they have ſtarted me for game, and after keeping them at bay, by ſouſing in a flood of water, I take to cover; that is, I put on Lady Sarah Savage's cloathes to avoid paſſing for a wild beaſt; mum!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: If he does but get out of the houſe, the marriage is broken off and Darnley made happy.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah Savage
sp.p: I'm at home to nobody but Mr. Darnley.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: We're undone, ruin'd; ſtay where you are; here's Lady Sarah.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: —The devil!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Huſh! lock yourſelf in, and don't ſtir till I tap at the door, or ſtop—ſtop—leſt ſhe or ſomebody elſe ſhould tap, don't open it till I give you a ſignal—let me ſee; what ſhall be the watchword? Oh, "quizzing," you won't forget "quizzing," Guardy.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No—I ſhall remember it theſe fifty years; ſo when I hear the word "quizzing," out I come, and—ſoftly—here ſhe is

div.stage: Enter Lady SARAH, with pocket-book and tickets in her hand.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Tell my dear Signor, I ſhall get rid of all theſe benefit tickets; heh! (taking out her ſpying glaſs.)—what young creature's this?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: How d'ye do again ma'am?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Again! you're vaſtly forward child; I never ſaw you before.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No ma'am! that's very ſtrange; you ſaw me this morning at Mr. Darnley's, and invited me to your houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Oh, ay: now I recollect; you muſt excuſe me; we people of rank are ſo very abſent; we're extremely intimate with a perſon in the morning, and don't know them at night; well! I'm vaſtly glad to ſee you; but you muſtn't ſtay here, I'm engaged child.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I ſhan't intrude, ma'am—good day.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Adieu! ſtop—ſtop—I forgot; give me two guineas.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Two guineas, ma'am!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Yes: for theſe tickets; they're for the Signor's wife's benefit at Bath next Monday,
the whole town will be there—nay, I ſhall attend—I'd make you take more, but as you'll have to pay card money bye and bye, it would be aſking you to one's houſe abſolutely to make a bargain of you! (Clara gives the two guineas.) there—you may go.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: A bargain indeed! and a bad one too: for if I was mean enough to make money by my gueſts, would I lay it out on foreigners who loll in carriages? no—not while ſo many of our gallant ſoldiers and ſailors have only wooden limbs to ſtand on! (half aſide.) I am gone, ma'am, (curtſeying.) and now may Darnley get out of the ſcrape—Sir Paul get out of the houſe—and ſhe and her brother knock their ſtupid heads together.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe this ſilly creature has interrupted the charming Mr. Darnley, and he has ſtept into my dreſſing room— (goes to the door and finds it faſten'd.)—lock'd inſide—it muſt be ſo— (liſtens)—I declare I hear him moving; (ſhe liſtens again)—he ſighs!—poor man! (ſhe ſpeaks loudly.)—don't be dejected, my dear ſir; when I'm married to that old tottering beau, Sir Paul, I'll think of nothing but you. So come, Mr. Darnley, (Enter Mrs. Darnley,) come my ſweet Mr. Darnley.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Can it be poſſible?—then all's confirm'd madam, when I am convinced that my huſband—that Mr. Darnley has been decoyed into that room.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Bleſs me!—its Mrs. Darnley!—this is a little aukward—however I'll ſoon talk her out of it, (aſide.) Don't be uneaſy, my dear—theſe faſhionable intrigues are
very harmleſs, I'll aſſure you, and if you had had my free and liberal education—but poor thing! I ſuppoſe you were ſent to ſchool for inſtruction.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnley.
sp.p: To ſchool! as certainly ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: There it is then: for what could you learn! only to ſing well enough to ſpoil converſation—to play on the harpſichord, ſo as to give papa, mama, and the whole family an afternoon's nap—to dance ſo aukwardly as to be always out of tune and place; and to ſpeak juſt French enough, to make you forget Engliſh; this is a boarding ſchool education—But I my dear—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Hear me, madam! when I firſt ſaw you, I was the happieſt of women—I had a huſband who lov'd and honour'd me—who doated on his children, and knew no pleaſure but in his family! and now how ſevere is the reverſe! you have robb'd me of that treaſure, ſeduc'd it from my heart, and I return to a melancholy home, without a friend for my own diſtreſſes, or a father for my children!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: And how can I help it?—didn't I mean to do you both a ſervice by introducing you to the great world?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Great world!—there again, madam!—when I enter'd this houſe, I expected from the exalted rank of its owner to have been ſurrounded with kindneſs, elegance, and hoſpitality!—but I find that high birth doesn't create high breeding, nor am I, becauſe humbly born, leſs likely to ſet a poliſh'd example than yourſelf—Oh Darnley! why will you not come forth and ſave your once lov'd wife from agonies too great to bear.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: So Savage—here's a pretty ſtory buzz'd about!—they ſay that Darnley, the country 'ſquire, is lock'd up in your dreſſing-room! if this is true you Jezabel—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Scandalous brute!—but I don't wonder at it, you've had ſuch a low vulgar education.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: I had an education!—well that's more than ever you had!—but look'ye, Miſs, no time muſt be loſt; for if Sir Paul diſcovers your intriguing, he'll break off the marriage, and we are ruin'd—yes; ruined madam! (to Mrs. Darnley,) you and your infamous huſband will make your own plots and marr mine—ſo I'll unkennel him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Hold, ſir—indeed he is not to blame—he was betray'd into that room.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Betray'd!—nay, then I muſt confeſs, brother, that Mr. Darnley is there; I dare ſay he conceal'd himſelf on purpoſe to expoſe me to Sir Paul—nay, I am ſure of it now.

sp.speaker: Savage,
sp.p: I ſee him through the key-hole—the raſcal's in diſguiſe! (enter two ſervants.) John call up the club—unlooſe the hounds—tell the whole houſe to prepare for quizzing—quizzing, you rogue.—

div.stage: Sir PAUL dreſs'd in Lady SAVAGE'S Great Coat, &c. opens the door, endeavours to eſcape, but meeting Mr. SAVAGE retires again directly.

sp.speaker: Savage
sp.p: —John, open the back-door, and ſhew the diſguis'd gentleman out of the houſe directly—go—and as for you Mrs. Darnley—

div.stage: DARNLEY enters, and Mrs. DARNLEY, Lady SARAH, and SAVAGE, ſtand aſtoniſhed.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Confuſion!—Darnley!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Is he then innocent?—Oh Harry!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Amazing! why, who was that wretch in my coat, hat, and tippet!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No leſs a gentleman than Sir Paul Perpetual—Clara told me the whole ſtory—he put on that diſguiſe to avoid the ſnares that were laid for him, and he has ere this left the houſe, determined to break off an union, that would have undone me and my family—lady Sarah, I entreat your pardon; but here (taking Mrs. Darnley by the hand,) here is my apology.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, I have ſhewn the diſguis'd gentleman down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Go to the devil with you.—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Brother!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Siſter!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: We are the fools that are outwitted.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Yes: we've turn'd out the wrong man—but let's purſue and overtake him inſtantly; come,—'ſquire, I inſiſt you leave my houſe directly, and as to you Miſs—if I catch the young gentleman, I'll have ſome ſport, I'm determined—I'll turn you both looſe amongſt the hounds below, and the Club ſhall decide, whether
ther old P. isn't the prettieſt looking female of the two!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I reſolved, Maria, to meet any cenſure, rather than give a pang to ſuch a heart as yours; but let us be gone—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Ay: let us return to our villa, nor ever wander more.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No—not yet Maria.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Not yet!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No—I have a plan to execute—Sir George, my beſt of friends, has invited us both to his aunt's houſe at Bath, and is now waiting without to conduct us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Do not go! let me entreat you; do not—I have a thouſand fears.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Nay, nay: he will introduce us to friends, who can render us eſſential ſervice; come—come—indulge me—the ſociety will be pleaſant, and unlike this ill-bred ſcene—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Well! if it muſt be ſo—Ah, Harry! I have now paſs'd hours in the humble and exalted ſcenes of life, and I find that good breeding is confin'd to no rank or ſituation! it conſiſts in good ſenſe, and good humour, and I believe we may ſee as large a ſhare of it under the roof of the cottage, as in the ſplendid manſions of the great!

div.head: ACT III.

SCENE I.—A ſuperb room in FLUSH'S houſe; handſome ſideboard of Plate—Pictures in elegant Frames—gilded chairs—two ſervants in fine liveries, putting ſilver coffee pot, tea urn, &c. on the table for breakfaſt, a third ſervant ſhewing in READY.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Tell your maſter, his agent deſires to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Fluſh is hardly dreſt yet.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Not up!—why it's two o'clock.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Very likely, ſir—my maſter ſeldom riſes ſooner—beſides he gave a grand ſupper laſt night; all the firſt people in Bath were preſent, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Well! well! tell him Mr. Ready is here: (Servant exit.) now isn't it amazing that a man who was only twelve years ago clerk to a lottery-office-keeper in London, ſhould be ſo rich, and ſo viſited, and how has he done all this? how, but by the modern myſtery of money lending!—by opening a ſhop in the city for linens, gauzes; and muſlins—by keeping a fine houſe near Bond ſtreet, and another in Bath. His ſon manages in London, and I here, while he by not appearing, is every where noticed and reſpected.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: James! Thomas! tell the cook to ſend a plan of my dinner.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: He's ſuch an epicure! and he, who formerly could ſcarcely get neceſſaries, is now not ſatisfied with luxuries.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Ha! Ready! how d'ye do, Ready?

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Sit down, Ready—ſit down. (Ready ſits.) well! how go on money matters?

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: I have alter'd the advertiſement as you deſir'd, and inſerted it in the Bath and Briſtol papers.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Read it—read it. (Takes up a pine apple on the breakfaſt table) You ſcoundrels! (to the ſervants.) is this a pine apple for a gentleman? buy a larger; buy one if it coſts ten pounds; I can afford it—read, Ready, read.

p.q: Money matters!—the nobility, gentry, ladies of faſhion, officers of rank, bankers, &c. may be ſecretly accommodated with money to any amount, on perſonal ſecurity only, by applying to P. O. Holly Street, Bath—No. 93.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Excellent! well! does the trap fill! have you caught any birds?

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Plenty; plenty of pigeons already; (Takes out his pocket-book.) here, here's a note for five hundred—left by a daſhing young parſon—I think it's good.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: It is—treat him well; give him value; I can afford it.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Value! but in what manner, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p:
Oh! pay him in the old way, Ready; firſt, give him my draft at a week for
thirty guineas, then offer him damag'd linen and muſlin to the amount of one hundred and twenty, and bid him call again in a fortnight—you have his note all the time you know.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Certainly, ſir; and when he calls—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Give him a bad bill for one hundred and fifty, and pay him the odd hundred in trifles; ſuch as paſte buckles, gilt bracelets, Weſtphalia hams, painted prints, neats tongues, and Stilton cheeſes—ſo ſhake hands, and have done with Maſter Parſon.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: But not with the bill, ſir.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: No—my bankers diſcount it, and pay it away, till paſſing through different hands, ſomebody gives value for it at laſt, and then the glorious work begins—then comes the hero into combat! an attorney is employ'd! an attorney, my boy! action is brought upon action! declaration filed upon declaration! till the drawer, acceptor, and indorſers all get into the King's Bench—the King's Bench—no—I beg pardon; the high money-lenders, and low attornies, have ſo fill'd it, with their dupes, that there isn't room there—the houſe overflows! ſo Newgate, Newgate is the ſhop!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Here's your ſon! juſt arriv'd from London!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Shew him in.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: I'm told, ſir, Mr. Gingham is quite another man, ſince I ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, you knew his curſt, ingenuous, candid diſpoſition; he learnt it in the country, the dog would ſpeak the truth, and his ſimplicity
ſo injur'd our trade, that I threatened to turn him out of doors; but he has reform'd Ready! the boy has the good ſenſe to tell a lie now, and I've ſent for him to witneſs his bleſſed reformation.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Ay, ſir, your ſon always ſpoke his mind too freely—in ſhort, Mr. Gingham was too honeſt for his profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: He was; however he has given me his word, never to ſpeak what comes uppermoſt, and he is now what he ought to be; a regular, ſolemn, jeſuitical—in ſhort—he's a very promiſing young man.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Sir, your hand—Ready yours, well! here I am—quite converted—like father, like ſon—tell a lie without bluſhing.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Here—I told you ſo—ay, ay, I knew the boy would come to ſomething good at laſt—ſo my dear boy you've left off telling the truth—ſpeaking your mind.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Mum! cloſe as the cabinet—keep you in my eye—put on your face, and do it ſo punctually, you wouldn't know young P. O. from yourſelf— (Looking about the room,) zounds! what a fine houſe you've got! how its furniſh'd! what plate! what pictures!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: The reſult of trade and honeſt induſtry, Frank—yes—its pretty furniture isn't it?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Pretty furniture! it's ſo handſome, that except yourſelf, curſe me, if I ſee a ſhabby bit in the room!—nay, nay, upon my ſoul, I didn't allude to you; I meant Ready.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: He's at his old tricks I ſee—as candid as ever.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Plague on't! I could ſooner bite off my tongue, than ſtop its ſpeaking what I think! nay, ſir, now pray.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Well, well, I excuſe you this once; I, a ſhabby bit! however we ſhall ſoon ſee—how goes on the ſhop in London?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: The ſhop!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Ay, the ſhop in the city that you've the care of—the linens—the—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Oh ay: now I recollect; why very well upon the whole, I believe, ſir—very well—only between ourſelves; I'm afraid it won't laſt; I think we and our tricks ſhall be found out—you underſtand—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Found out! 'ſblood, ſirrah—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Softly ſir—ſoftly—don't put yourſelf in a paſſion, and lay the blame on me; don't charge me with our ruin, for every body knew my opinion long ago; didn't they, Ready? I told it to a thouſand people—ſays I, "ſwindling will never thrive, and I and my poor father ſhall get duck'd at laſt!"

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: You did! did you?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: That I did, ſir; and I'll prove I ſaid ſo—the other night I ſlept at the weſt end, and two friends—diſtreſs'd old officers in the army—brought their notes to be diſcounted—ſays I, Gentlemen, it won't do—you'll get little caſh, but a quantity of trumpery nonſenſe, ſuch as hams, cheeſes, prints, linens, and other vegetables! ſaid they; we know that—we know you and your father are two infernal ſharpers, but a guinea now is worth ten a month hence—ſo give us the money.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Well: and you took their note, didn't you?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No, I didn't—I gave them the caſh, ſhook the two old ſoldiers by the hand, and ſaid I was tir'd of ſuch d—d ſwindling practices.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: This is ſad work, Mr. Gingham you'll never be at the top of your profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: The top!—Oh! what the pillory? no—I leave that to you, Ready!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a ſcoundrel?—but we'll hear more, (aſide.)—So, you ſleep at the weſt end of the town, do you?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Always—its vulgar to be in the city of an evening; beſides I like to walk in Kenſington-gardens in the morning—You know Kenſington-gardens, father—the place where there's ſuch a mixture of green leaves and brown powder—of blue violets and yellow ſhoes; and where there's ſuch a croud, that to get air and exerciſe you ſtand a chance of broken bones and ſuffocation!—Well!—there I ſtrut away, my boys—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: You do—do you?—I can hardly keep my hands off the raſcal—So then I ſuppoſe, the moment my back was turn'd, you never thought of buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Buſineſs!—no never—Did I, Ready? I recollected my father play'd the ſame game before me; that when he was clerk at the lottery-office, at billiards all the morning, and at hazard all the evening—therefore, ſays I, where's the difference?—none! but that he had the policy to conceal his tricks, and I the folly to ſhew mine—heh! I'm right—an't I, Ready?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p:
You villain!—is this your reformation? not even conceal your own faults, much more
mine. Expoſe my character, neglect my trade, and ſtrut away in Kenſington-gardens! I have done with you from the country you came, and to the country you ſhall return—Speak the truth, indeed! zounds! ſirrah, what has truth to do with money lending!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh, Guardy—I'm juſt come to Bath with Mr. and Mrs. Darnley—we are all on a viſit at Sir George Gauntlet's, and—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Its only my ſon, Clara—a ſimple fooliſh young man.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: More knave than fool, upon my honour, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: The gentleman don't praiſe himſelf I ſee, Mr. Fluſh.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No, ma'am—nor do I know any body that will praiſe me—unleſs my father indeed.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Silence, ſir!—well: but about the rural pair, my dear ward; do you know I have a great regard for Mr. and Mrs. Darnley.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Have you? I'm vaſtly glad of that for your joint guardian, Sir Paul, is ſo employ'd in ſeeking for his loſt child, that he has forgot his promiſe to aſſiſt Darnley; therefore I want you to do him a favour.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: A favour!—he may command me.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
The caſe is this—his increaſe of family has ſo enlarg'd his expences, that he has thoughts of returning to the army—Sir George has promiſed to procure him a company, but Mrs. Darnley, not chuſing he ſhould owe his promotion to him, wiſhes he ſhould purchaſe; now,
Guardy, if you would lend him two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Two hundred pounds, child!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ay, two hundred pounds, father!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Who bid you ſpeak, ſir?—Why, Clara, in money matters there is an etiquette.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: True: but this is your friend.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: So it is, ma'am: the man he has a great regard for.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And when you conſider the charms of Mrs. Darnley, and the wants of her children—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: He can't refuſe, ma'am—indeed he don't intend it—and therefore as I ſee he means to grant the favour, I'll ſave him the trouble of putting his hand in his pocket—Here, ma'am! (taking out bank notes) here are two bank notes of a hundred each—they belong to Mr. Fluſh—now they belong to Mr. Darnley— (Fluſh gets in his way and prevents Clara's taking them.)—he begs you'll give them to his friend—and preſent his compliments—and ſay, he'll double the ſum.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Stand off—ſtand off—or by heavens I'll—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.stage: (Offering Clara the notes acroſs his father)
sp.p: Double the ſum, whenever call'd upon, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, or I'll knock it down your throat, ſirrah.—I ſay, Clara, in the the way of buſineſs, I've no objection to do Mr. Darnley a ſervice; that is, if I can make a profit by it—firſt, he ſhould ſend me his note.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Here it is, ſir.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: That's right—now we can proceed—here, ſir— (Giving the note to Gingham,) take the note to my agent, and tell him to give Mr. Darnley thirty pounds—I can afford it.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: This is too bad—take in his own friend, and a man with a family, (aſide.) Sir,—a word if you pleaſe—I told you, we were all blown upon—now, here's an opportunity for retrieving our reputation—lend him the two hundred pounds—prove, for once, we can behave like gentlemen, and hark'ye—we ſhan't reach the top of the profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: This is beyond bearing—quit the room directly—'sdeath!—leave my houſe, ſir—begone!—I diſinherit you—I—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Lord!—why ſo angry, guardian?—I'm ſure he is a good young man, and as warm in his heart—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Warm in his heart!—nonſenſe!—will he be warm in the funds? no—never—while he is ſo candid—ſo—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Not while he is candid, ſir?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: No—do you think I made my fortune by candour or openneſs; anſwer me, ſir—did I ever get a ſhilling by ſpeaking the truth— ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No, ſir, I never ſaid you did—I know the contrary, ſir; madam, I'm of a communicative diſpoſition, I own; but there are many ſecrets of my father's I never blabb'd.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Are there, ſir?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Yes, that there are, ſir.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: I don't recollect them.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Don't you? Why, now, did I ever mention, ſir, that you got theſe pictures by ſueing out execution? That you got that plate, by its being pawn'd to you for half its value; that you intrigue with a female money-lender; and that the laſt time you were made a bankrupt,
you went to get your certificate ſigned in a new vis-a-vis? did I, or will I ever mention theſe things?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Begone, ſir—I'll never ſee you more— Yet, ſtay—you have papers in your poſſeſſion —meet me in an hour's time at my agent's, ſir, —at Mr. Ready's.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Forgive me this once, father—I'll never let the cat out any more.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: No, ſir, I never will forgive you— I am engaged, ſir, and you know we great men are ſelect in our company.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Well, if it muſt be ſo—farewell, father! the world is all before me, and what trade to follow, heaven only knows. Good bye, madam!—your ſex will never befriend me, becauſe I can't keep a ſecret, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I will befriend you, ſir; for while there is ſo much deception and hypocriſy in the world, it would indeed be unjuſt, not to approve ſuch frankneſs and honeſty. Guardy, let me intercede for him; I'll anſwer for his conduct.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Aye; and if ever I mention ducking or ſwindling again.—There! you ſee he's fix'd, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: At preſent he is, and therefore leave him, perhaps by the time you meet him at the agent's I ſhall have talked him into good humour. Adieu! depend on't, I ſhan't forget your generous intentions.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Nor ſhall I, yours; and if fortune ſmiles on me, I'll prove that I deſerve your kindneſs—If ever my father pardons—but I ſee he's more and more angry, ſo I take my leave. May every bleſſing attend you—may you meet with a heart as liberal as your own—May your
couſins' diſtreſſes vaniſh—may your guardian once more value a ſon, who can't help ſpeaking the truth for the ſoul of him.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Upon my word he's a charming man! and pardon him you muſt, Guardy, if its only to pleaſe me.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: No—I'm determined.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: The dinner's ready.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Come, Clara, you ſhall dine with me; I want to talk to you, and if I cou'd ſee my joint Guardian, Sir Paul—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I met him at your door—he's only juſt gone by.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Juſt gone by! that's a miſtake; for the old beau has been gone by theſe thirty years: however, come in—come, and eat and drink what you like. Call for burgundy, champagne, or tokay—Ay, call for tokay at a guinea a pint; I can afford it, my dear Ward, I can afford it.

div.head: SCENE II.—The Creſcent and the ſurrounding country.
div.stage: Enter Lady SARAH SAVAGE, and Sir GEORGE GAUNTLET.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Sir George, I own my weakneſs: the proud, the haughty lady Sarah is humbled; Darnley has enſnared my heart, and one way or other, I muſt inſure his pity—Heigho! you are his friend, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: You ſee I am; and that he eſteems me more than ever, is evident from his bringing Mrs. Darnley to my houſe—did you mind his orders to her?—take an airing my dear with Sir George in his phaeton! it will raiſe your ſpirits, my love!—Ha! ha! he abſolutely throws her into my arms.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Yes; but ſhe abſolutely contrives to get out of them again.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: She does; and therefore, there is no way but the one I mentioned—we muſt make Darnley jealous.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: True:—I'll tell him that you love his wife.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Nay, nay, not me—fix on ſomebody elſe—we'll ſoon find an object, and then by convincing him of her falſehood, he naturally turns his thoughts to another woman; which is you, you know—and ſhe wanting a protector, conſequently flies to another man, which is me, you know we'll add the Signor to the confederacy.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: You're a ſad wretch—a ſad wretch indeed, Sir George, to impoſe on a friend, who places ſuch confidence—ſuch—I won't hear you—poſitively I won't hear you—only obſerve, if I don't win the cruel Darnley's affections, I'll drive my Phaeton down a precipice in reality; I will, or with the bayonet of my fuſil, pierce my too tender heart, and expire at his feet.

div.stage: Enter the honourable Mr. SAVAGE haſtily.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: So Sarah—I and Sir Paul have had ſuch an adventure!—though we quarrel'd laſt night, we made it up to day; for I never think alike two hours together—Do you, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Never: but when I think of you brother, then I think more than I ſay, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: No; you ſay more than you think, I aſſure you—but would you believe it? The old boy has ſeen his ſon,—we trac'd him from the ſtage coach he came in, to the pump room, from the pump room, to the billiard room—there Sir Paul ſaw him playing with the marker, and when he heard the young man's name, he fainted; actually fainted in my arms.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: What, in a fit! poor old man! well! if you'll believe me, Sir George, I never ſaw a perſon in a fit in all my life.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Long before he recover'd, the young man was gone—the bird was flown—for the ſtanders by, all blacklegs began laying betts on Sir Paul's recovery, and thoſe who were againſt him, wouldn't let water be thrown in his face.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Inhuman wretches!—they ought to have ſous'd him to death: but pray, brother, who is this child? where does he come from? what's the ſtory?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Why—about twenty years ago, Sir Paul's lady quarrell'd with him at Tunbridge, and married a citizen—Four months after the marriage ſhe had a ſon, which the citizen brought up as his own, and Sir Paul now ſwears the boy was his—'gad! it will be curious; for the child will have two fathers.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Curious! not at all—but why ſhould you meddle?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Becauſe it ſecures me the two beſt racers in his ſtud—Fidget and Fizgig; and what's better, becauſe it ſtill ſecures us Sir Paul's fortune: for though he won't marry you himſelf, he intends his ſon ſhould; and, if I could but once more ſee the young man—I know he goes by his mother's name— (Looking out) heh! its him! there he is again!—get out of the way; don't interrupt—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: No—I have too great a regard for Sir Paul's property to interrupt any plan for ſecuring it; beſides, Sir George and I have buſineſs—come—I ſay brother, tell the old gentleman to be careful, and in his eagerneſs bid him not claim another man's child inſtead of his own!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Where can Sir Paul be loitering? he ſaid he'd follow me—mum!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Oh! what a whirligig world is this? I that was brought up to lend money; muſt now try to borrow it: but where? who'll truſt a wandering linen-draper! who'll truſt the notorious young P. O.? however, Iv'e got my equivalent; I can ſpeak my mind now—no longer need I ſmother my thoughts, and be ready to burſt: no longer have an itching on my tongue, and be ready to bite it in two—no, no, I may open now. The ſweet lady ſends me word my father is inexorable, but hopes ſhe ſhall ſoon ſee me again; heigho! I hope ſo too; when I think of her, my heart feels ſuch queer ſenſations—I have it: ſhe has taken leſſons of my father, and ſwindled me out of my affections; but then my poverty— I can never indulge even a hope.— (Sees Mr. Savage.)—Ha! here's the friend of the queer old gentleman, who fainted in the billiard room.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Sir, the honourable Henry Savage has the pleaſure—the felicity—What are you—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: the honourable?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Ay: why didn't you know it?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No: nor never ſhould if you hadn't told me—ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! you're a droll dog! 'gad! you ſhall come to my houſe, and paſs a week with me.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Faith! a year with all my ſoul! I've nothing to do with myſelf; I've left off trade; haven't change for ſixpence in the world,
and ſo my little right honourable—I'll honour you with my company.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Huſh! if you want money don't own it: we great people are cloſe—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I know it; oeconomical too!—you live cheap.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: What! people of faſhion live cheap?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: To be ſure; you don't pay; and if that iſn't living cheap, the devil's in't!—ha! here's the fainting gentleman again!—who the deuce is he?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: I fancy you'll find him a pretty near relation of yours—at leaſt, if you were born at Tunbridge, and your mother's name was Gingham.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: It was; that's the name of her, and of the town.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Say you ſo?— (Enter Sir Paul Perpetual,)—The racers are mine, Sir Paul!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay: my whole ſtud—any thing: every thing! only let me have another peep at my dear boy!—only let me prove to poſterity!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: There he is!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Where!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: There! there is your ſon! who was born at Tunbridge—whoſe mother's name was Gingham, and who is now without a ſhilling in his pocket, or a friend in the world—joy! joy! old boy! you've got a young P. at laſt!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Stand off! let me come at him; come to thy father's arms!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay: thy real father! who has a fortune to beſtow on thee, and health, youth, and ſpirits to ſhare in all thy pleaſures—The dog has my right eye to a T.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Pray does your friend bite in his fits?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Hark'ye—its Sir Paul Perpetual! better known by the name of old P.—he has an immenſe property.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Has he?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Yes: and if its certain you are his ſon, he'll give you every farthing of it.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Oh! if that's the caſe—if he has an immenſe property—let me ſee who dare deny it? Sir, your bleſſing!— (kneeling.)—I always ſaid I wasn't my father's own child.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Riſe my boy! my darling! and tell us how the citizen educated you!—The turn of my noſe exactly!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I've done with linens, gauzes, and muſlins now!—let the ſhop and all its ſwindling go to the bottom—I'm the ſon of Sir Paul Perpetual, better known by the name of old P. I'm not a tradeſman —.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Tradeſman!—zounds!—my ſon brought up in a ſhop! — how it freezes my warm blood!—look'ye, my boy—two things I muſt requeſt of you—never to talk about trade, or mention your former father's name.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Never—I'll never mention his name becauſe I deſpiſe it; but as to trade, what's bred in the bone, you know father —

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well—well—come to Mr. Savage's houſe; there we'll introduce you to your intended wiſe—Miſs Savage will ſoon break you of talking about trade, or the city—ſo come along.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Ay: pray give up the city—the rich rogues have no taſte for us men of wit and genius—they eſtimate every thing by property,
and if the great Ben Jonſon—nay, if the great Big Ben were alive, is there one citizen would give the poor dogs a dinner?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No—you're right there; in the city a man that has no money, has no wit—the ſmalleſt bank note is more entertaining than the wittieſt manuſcript; and talk of Ben Jonſon's name for jokes—damme, Abraham Newland beats him hollow! isn't it true, my boy?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: As true, as that you beat my other father hollow—come—henceforth, no money lending tricks for me. But young P. O. ſhall ſtick to gay old P.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I.—A Drawing-Room in Mr. SAVAGE'S Houſe at Bath.
div.stage: Enter Sir GEORGE GAUNTLET and Signor CYGNET.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Bravo! Signor braviſſimo!—and ſo Lady Sarah Savage has actually perſuaded Darnley, that his wife loves another man?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Si—at firſt he no believe—but Lady Sarah lay it down with ſuch courâge—her oaths were ſo ſuperbe, and mine ſo magnifique, that 'at laſt he accompany us with tears—pauvre Miſter Darnley!—Ah! ha!—you no forget my vife's concert.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: And who did you ſay Mrs. Darnley was attached to?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Attendez—Sir Paul—what you call—old P.—he has found one child—eh bien!—the enfant was at the comedie, and ſaw Madame Darnley and her 'couſin maltraité by ſome qu'on appelle bobbies—villains who fight de duels, and interrupt de muſic—Vell! de child relieve de ladies, conduct them home—ſup, and dough all de time he make love to Mad'moiſelle Clara—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Yet, Lady Sarah Savage fixes on him for Mrs. Darnley's gallant—excellent! and if this ſcheme fails, I underſtand ſhe has another—there is Mr. Fluſh—a ſort of money agent.
