sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Je connois—je connois—he make a you poor, by lending you caſh.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: This Mr. Fluſh has got Darnley's note for two hundred pounds—now he can't pay it; and therefore if Lady Sarah Savage buys it up—

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Je comprehende—ſhe ſay, give me my heart, or pay me my money—ah ha!—I ſee you will be the firſt fiddle yourſelf;— (looking out.) le voici!—here is Mr. Fluſh!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: No—it's Sir Paul and the ſon you ſpoke of—good day Signor—and if you ſee Darnley, tell him I'm out of town.

sp.speaker: Signor
sp.p: I vill! — ecoutez—I no like to meet this Sir Paul—ven he aſk me to his houſe, he always ſing himſelf—toujours—if he has de cold—de ſore throat—il chante! and begar: he ſing as well with the hoarſeneſs, as without—bon-jour, Sir George—bon-jour— (going, recollects and turns back.) Ah ha!—you no forget my vife's concert?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Darnley, jealous of his wife! and ſhe under my own roof!—now, if I can perſuade her to retaliate—here's her ſuppoſed gallant.

div.stage: Enter Sir PAUL and GINGHAM, elegantly dreſſed.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I tell you, father, Clara Sedley is the girl of my heart!—your ward is the girl for young P.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Nonſenſe!—haven't I made you a gentleman—ſtuck a ſword by your ſide?—haven't I brought you here to addreſs Lady Sarah Savage?—ha! Sir George!—now mind (to Gingham) and conceal your low education—not a word about trade or the warehouſe; for I mean to put you into the army, and I've told every
body you've been on your travels.—Sir George!—my ſon!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Sir, I'm very proud of the honour.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Sir!—I'm very proud of— (bowing up to him, and ſpying at his chitterlin)—right India muſlin, by all that's—mum!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: You've been a great traveller, ſir,—much abroad?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Abroad!—yes, ſir—I was ſeldom at home—generally at the Weſt End, for between ourſelves, though I was brought up to trade, I always deſpis'd the warehouſe—always—pſhaw!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Zounds!—mind what you're at—conſider, if you talk as my ſon, about linens and the warehouſe, they'll take your father for a tradeſman; they'll ſay I'm a haberdaſher, knighted on a city addreſs!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: A haberdaſher!—that's a good one, a very good one—upon my ſoul; Sir George, my father is'nt ſuch a fool, as you take him for—no—that he isn't—are you, father?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah Savage.
sp.p: When Mr. Fluſh comes, ſhew him up ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Here's your intended wife, ſir—'gad! I hope it will be a match, for Lady Sarah is ſo anxious for a huſband, that in the scramble, ſhe might ſeize me at laſt—come, Sir Paul—let's leave the happy pair together.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Now, remember what I told you—Lady Sarah is the eſſence of faſhion and good breeding; and if you want to poliſh, and rub off the city-ruſt, imitate her—copy her elegant manner.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Ay: ſhe's the rage!—and, if he wants to ſecure her affections, bid him imitate
his father, Sir Paul—copy you, and he muſt ſucceed with the women.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, that he muſt, Sir George—there's not a girl at Newmarket, not a dancer at the opera, or a ſinger at the ancient concert, but adores me—they treat me with the ſame reſpect they would a father—they ſay I'm ſo quiet—ſo inoffenſive—ſo harmleſs.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Harmleſs! do they ſay you're harmleſs, father?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, harmleſs, and under that idea, I've done more miſchief, then any ten dangerous men in Europe—So copy her manners, and ſucceſs to you, my boy!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Bravo! theſe are fine times, Maſter Gingham,—but will they laſt?—is there no trick play'd, or to be play'd thee?—Sir Paul I'm told has a way of diſguiſing himſelf in women's cloathes, ſurely this is'nt another maſquerading affair—Ah! here's ſpouſe!—now to imitate her faſhionable manners.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Marry him, I will: becauſe in the firſt place, there's a ſcarcity of huſbands; and in the next, being his wife, ſecures Sir Paul's fortune, and makes Darnley for ever in my pow'r—beſides, I can draw the youth into all my ſchemes—hem!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Hem! (imitating her.) If this is a woman of faſhion, the breed is grown pretty bold I think.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
I muſt ſhew him my ſpirit—terrify him before marriage, in order to tame
him after. (Going towards him wriggling her head.) Sir!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Give me a chair!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: A chair, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Yes, a chair, ſir.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Eſſence of breeding!—ſhe's the eſſence of braſs! (brings her a chair.) A chair, ma'am!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: He little knows what a life I ſhall lead him.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Heh!—a chair, ma'am!—here's a chair, I ſay—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Oh, I forgot—I am really ſo abſent— (ſits down) he! he! he!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Are you really!—he! he! he!—I ſhould like to— (mimicking) imitate her manners! hang me if I dare—ſhe has ſet me all in a tremble—pheugh!
sp.stage: (Puffing himſelf with his hat, and drawing his chair from her.)

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Look up, my hero! (ſlapping him.) You can't think how I rejoice at your being deſigned for the army. I'm of a military, martial turn myſelf, and ſhall ſerve every campaign with you.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: You ſerve campaigns!—I wiſh I was out of the room—pheugh!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: I ſhall make an excellent ſoldier—a dauntleſs warrior! and if you talk of little unfledg'd fluttering enſigns, look at me—look!— (ſhaking him) march!—wheel about!—left!—make ready!—preſent!—fire!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.stage: (Looking firſt at her feet, then at her head.)
sp.p: It is—it is an impoſtor!—ugh!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Shan't I make a warlike appearance! animate one army, and intimidate another? reſtore the name of amazon—revive the age of chivalry, and if there are fools that threaten, and cowards that dread an invaſion; Oh! how the thought fires me!— (riſes,)—give me a few champions like myſelf, and we'll ſtand on our white cliffs, and ſcare away whole nations.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Damme, it's another man in woman's cloathes! don't agitate yourſelf—be compos'd— (to her as ſhe walks about.) what would I give to be ſnug behind the counter?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: I am no timid helpleſs woman; I can ſhoot—I can fence—flouriſh a ſword, or fire off a muſket!—penetrate your ſword arm at the firſt thruſt, or lodge a bullet in your forehead at forty yards.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Keep cool—my hero keep cool! Oh! it's a clear caſe—it's a man, and here am I to rub off the ruſt, by being run through the body! ſit down my fine fellow! ſit down.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Fine fellow!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ay, I ſee how it is—Sir Paul has adopted me out of joke, and you are to make mince meat of me for my vanity!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Why, what is all this! (ſmiling.) mince meat!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: He ſmiles! then the joke's at an end, and they don't mean to hurt me! give me your hand—you comical dog, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Comical dog! what do you mean? explain.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Explain! nay: that's too bad—do you think I don't know you my jolly boy?—do you think I can't ſee you are a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: What! I a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ay, and a brave one too!—why I ſuſpected you at firſt ſight!—I ſaw there was nothing feminine about you, and then when I looked you full in the face, "pooh," ſays I, this can never be a woman!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Not a woman!—have I ſtudied modern faſhions? exceeded all the preſent race of high ſpirited women! only to be miſtaken for—Oh Lord! I never wept before in all my life—but this—Oh, I ſhall faint—Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: My raſcal of a ſon has gone off with all my papers—Darnley's note amongſt the number—and though Lady Sarah would give twice the value for it, I cannot find him—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Huſh! not ſo loud father—he'll flouriſh a ſword—fire off a muſket!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: He!—who!—but how came you here, ſir? in this diſguiſe too!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Phoo!—it isn't me that's diſguis'd; a word— (whiſpers to him)—there!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: What! that lady!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No; that comical dog—I'm ſure of it—mum!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha!—you blockhead! why it's Lady Sarah Savage! ſhe's rather maſculine to be
ſure: but Lord help you—ſhe and I are old friends.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: What! you know her? do you!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Know her!—why I'll take my oath ſhe's a woman.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: He'll take his oath!—Oh then I ſee my error—ſhe's on the pavé, diſcarded; and they want to palm her on me.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Fool!—would you make more blunders! can't you tell a women of faſhion from a—.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No—there it is, ſir,—if women of faſhion will talk and dreſs like women of another deſcription, who the devil can tell one from the other! and, if likewiſe they will hunt, ſhoot, and fence, and prefer maſçuline aſſurance, to feminine diffidence, is it amazing, that a gentleman ſhould confound the ſexes? however, I'm glad it's not a man.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Come—come—without further enquiry, give me Darnley's note; the one Clara brought; the comical dog there, as you call her, is in love with Darnley, and wants to hold the bill as a rod over his head: I ſhall only aſk her one hundred pounds premium for it.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.stage: (Taking the note out of his pocket book.)
sp.p: Only a hundred premium! heh!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: No; I can afford it: and ſhe, by arreſting him, can make her own terms—you underſtand!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Perfectly; ſo I'll ſhew her the note, and make peace— (goes towards Miſs Savage, who is ſtill ſitting.)—madam—lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Pſhaw! don't come near me, brute.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I am convinc'd of my miſtake, ma'am—this gentleman will take his oath on the ſubject, and therefore—in hopes of making amends—here is a note, my lady; a note of Mr. Darnley's for two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: What did you ſay, ſir?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: A note of Mr. Darnley's, ma'am!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: So it is; ſign'd with his own dear hand— (riſes)—well, now I look at you again, ſir, I'm quite aſham'd of our ſilly miſunderſtanding—I am indeed—he! he! perhaps it was my fault—nay—I dare ſay it was—and ſo, that's Mr. Darnley's note, is it?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: It is, and now I recollect, wasn't the lady I conducted from the play, his wife?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: It was—but entre nous—what's the price of that fooliſh bit of paper?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Only three hundred pounds! one hundred for the premium, and two for the principal.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Here is the money then.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Softly; keep the principal, becauſe you'll both want it, and as to the note, I'll keep that, leſt ſomebody elſe ſhould want it! (putting it in his pocket,) you brought me up to the trade, and if I haven't learnt a trick or two, Mr. Fluſh, it's no fault of yours.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: What! would you turn ſwindler, you raſcal!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Ay, this is a new mode of getting money.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
No—not ſo very new—is it Mr. Fluſh?—however, as the wife is the only perſon that ought to have a pow'r over the huſband,
I'll e'en go inſtantly to Mrs. Darnley, and give it her.—

sp.speaker: Darnley,
sp.p: What, ſir?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: A note for two hundred pounds, ſir,—have you any objections? never mind the loſs of the premium, Mr. Fluſh—you can afford it, you know—adieu!—Mr. Bluff, (To Darnley, who is frowning,) your ſervant—it wouldn't do—you you comical dog, it wouldn't do!—

div.stage: (Shewing Lady Sarah Savage the note, and exit.)

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: 'Sdeath!—this is the very man you told me of.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Ay, now can you want further proof of his attachment to your wife?—I'll leave it to any body?—isn't it evident, Mr. Fluſh?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: His giving her two hundred pounds is a ſtrong circumſtance to be ſure—but then, when I recollect the money is mine, and not his—

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: What then, ſir.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Why then, I think, the lady ought to be in love with me, and not him, ſir.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I'll ſet out for London, and never ſee her more—yet no—I'll be ſatisfied—I'll know the worſt!—I'll inſtantly purſue this new found idol of her heart, and if I catch him in her preſence—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Kill him—for a wretch, who can't diſtinguiſh the human ſpecies, isn't fit to live—come—I'll go with you.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: So will I—but pray don't kill him, till I've got my papers.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Nay, don't fret about it, Mr. Darnley—you ſhall return with me to Savage-houſe—come—never think of going to London at this time of year—it's ſo thin—all the great houſes are lock'd up, and there's no making a faſhionable party; is there, Mr. Fluſh?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Your pardon, ma'am—I and my attorney can always collect a faſhionable party, and if the great houſes are lock'd up, why there are great people in lock-up-houſes, ſo don't be afraid of finding good company, Mr. Darnley!

div.head: SCENE II.—A library in Sir George Gauntlet's houſe.
div.stage: Sir GEORGE, and a ſervant meeting.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir! Sir! Mrs. Darnley is coming here to look for ſome books.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: That's fortunate: did you deliver my meſſage to her, and her huſband?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I did, ſir, I told them you were gone out of town, and would not return till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Very well! then, in caſe of accident, leave open the private door that leads behind the library. (Servant opens a door that leads behind the library.) A man of intrigue ſhould always have a place to lay ſnug in, and where is he ſo little likely to be diſcover'd, as amongſt works of ſtudy and reflection! here ſhe is!
mind we're not interrupted.
sp.stage: (Servant exit—Sir George retires towards the Library.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Will Mr. Darnley never be convinc'd of this friend's hypocriſy! he is ſo credulous, that he even now places more confidence in him, than ever: I'm glad Sir George is out of town—I can at leaſt paſs another hour in peace, and—
sp.stage: (Going towards the Library, Sir George meets her.)

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, Mrs. Darnley; I'm only a living volume, and if you will peruſe my thoughts, you'll read of nothing but yourſelf—you are engraved here in indelible letters, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Sir, I was inform'd—but this is no time for parleying—alone and unprotected!
sp.stage: (Going, Sir George ſtvnds in her way.)

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Nay, you know I have long profeſſed a regard for you; long thought you the fineſt woman on earth! and as a proof, didn't I offer you my hand, before my friend—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Friend! call him by ſome other name, Sir George, and don't profane ſuch honourable terms.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Why, isn't he my friend? havn't I ſo completely gain'd his affections, that he wiſhes me to win yours? does he not bring you here—to my houſe!—leave me tête-a-tête with you! and in every reſpect prove ſo kind, ſo obliging—.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Hold, ſir—if he has expoſed me to inſults, I am the perſon to accuſe him—not
you! I know his heart, and I know yours—one has my love—my eſteem—the other—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Has what, my ſweet creature?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: My ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Nay then—I muſt tell you, that when I condeſcend to love a woman, I always inſiſt on making her happy; and therefore, with opportunity on my ſide, and the whole world to lay the blame on your huſband—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: On him! the world is not ſo eaſily deceiv'd! but leſt it ſhould, I'll vindicate his fame—I'll proclaim the falſehood of his friend—his perfidy—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Gently—gently—I ſee I muſt take advantage now or never!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: What do you mean, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Firſt to faſten the door, and then, my angel—
sp.stage: (As he opens it to faſten it cloſely, Gingham enters and puſhes by him.)

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: And then, my angel—to give you two hundred pounds—this note, ma'am, is Mr. Darnley's—it accidentally fell into my hands, and I deſignedly place it in yours—put it up, ma'am—keep it tight in your pocket; for what, with one having a rage for diſguiſes—another having a rage for ſwindling—a third— (Seeing Sir George.)—ha! my judge of good breeding! is it you?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: This blockhead has ruin'd one ſcheme already, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I'll tell you a ſecret Sir George; you faſhionable people are very vulgar—it is your fine cloathes, gay equipages, and ſuperb houſes that are well bred, and not yourſelves, egad! now only pull off that ſpangled coat—ſtick yourſelf behind a counter, and—.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Sir, don't you ſee I'm buſy?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: To be ſure I do.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Why don't you leave the room then?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Becauſe I've no where elſe to go.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Then I command you; this lady and I are engag'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Engag'd, Sir George!—Sir, (to Gingham) if you'll conduct me to Mr. Darnley, I ſhall think myſelf a ſecond time indebted to your gallantry.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Madam, I inſiſt— (Croſſing Mrs. D. and taking her by the hand,)—retire this inſtant, Sir—retire—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Oh! I perceive—he detains her for baſe purpoſes! oh fie! fie!—fie for ſhame, Sir George—is this your good breeding!—your hand, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: 'Sdeath—obey me, or this ſword, with which I've ſo often fought.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Often fought! what in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Raſcal! draw.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No—I'd rather not.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: What! you don't like to fight!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No—who the devil does! but you call me raſcal, ſir—now I've been long in doubt whether I am one or not—but if I was half as clear on the ſubject as you muſt be, I'd own it publickly—I'd ſay, "I Sir George Gauntlet am ſuch a rude—ill bred—vulgar"—.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Coward!—come on—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Come on!—well! why ſhouldn't I! I may be alarm'd at maſculine women, but I don't care that— (Snapping his fingers,)—for effeminate
men! ſo, though I never learnt to fence in all my life—though I don't know whether to hold my ſword in my right hand or my left, have at thee!—ha!—ha!—

div.stage: Sir GEORGE and GINGHAM make two or three paſſes, when loud knocking at the door interrupts them.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Zounds!—if this ſhould be Darnley— (looks out.)—it is! I'm ruin'd—undone!—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I muſt take leſſons—I'm touch'd—pink'd—
sp.stage: (ſhaking his hand which is ſlightly wounded.)

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: If I ſtir, I meet Darnley—hark'ye Sir— (aſide to Gingham,)—that lady's huſband is now on the ſtairs, and your preſent wound is only a ſlight one; but if you hint or ſpeak one word againſt my honour—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: You'll run me through the body I ſuppoſe—well! as I can't fence—mum!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I ſhall not leave the room—I ſhall be conceal'd, and on the ſlighteſt inſinuation, by heaven! I'll come forth and cut you into atoms; promiſe—or—you know my way—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I do—I'll live and fight another day.

div.stage: Sir GEORGE goes behind the Library unperceiv'd by GINGHAM or by Mrs. DARNLEY.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I wiſh I knew the name of Sir George's fencing maſter— (Mrs. Darnley comes to him)—my dear ma'am, don't be uneaſy—it's only graz'd, and if they don't ſend doctors and apothecaries to me, I ſhall live to pink him, again and again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Let me bind your hand, with my handkerchief. (Darnley enters behind.) Indeed—indeed, I owe you much.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: 'Tis now beyond a doubt—Oh woman! woman!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: You hav'nt got the rage—no, you are what a woman ought to be; mild, gentle, affectionate—an angel by all that's ſacred.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: How! make love before my face! — (advances) So Mrs. Darnley —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnly.
sp.p: Oh my dear!—I'm ſo glad you're come — this gallant, generous young man —

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Generous young man!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Generous young man!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Has been wounded in my cauſe, and —

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: And you bound up his arm, with your handkerchief! —nay, don't deny it, madam—with my own eyes, I ſaw it—well, ſir! what have you to ſay, ſir? to that handkerchief, ſir?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Say, ſir!—why, I ſay, the handkerchief is as fine cambrick as ever was ſold—twelve ſhillings a yard, ſir!—at leaſt I uſed to ſell ſuch for a guinea—a guinea, Mr. Bluff—as to any thing elſe, if you are the lady's huſband —

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I am her huſband, ſir!—who has long lov'd—long ador'd her!—and now comes here to witneſs her falſehood and his own diſhonour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: What does he ſay?—diſhonour!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
Yes, madam—with him! with this gallant, generous young man! did he not laſt night accompany you from the play, and now do I not find you praiſing each other to my very
face?—obſerve me, Maria—as you have found me tender in my affections; ſo you ſhall find me ſevere in my reſentment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: I know not what he means: but I thought they'd make him hate me—I guilty of falſehood! diſhonour to my huſband! Oh, Harry! if you believe me ſo debas'd, take up that weapon, and pierce me to the heart!—in pity do!—I cannot live and know that you condemn me.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Do you not love him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Whom!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Him.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Me!—love me!—I wiſh ſhe did, for if I didn't uſe her better than you do, I'd cut my jealous head off!—look'ye, great lord and maſter!—ſhe is more faithful to you, than you deſerve—I know it, becauſe juſt before you enter'd the room, Sir George Gauntlet, like a vile ſeducer as he is, was attempting to — (here a book falls from the library.) crau—au—au! (checking himſelf.) I ſhall be a dead man, before I know it.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Sir George Gauntlet!—paltry evaſions!—he is out of town and has ſo often prov'd himſelf a friend. —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Friend!—Oh, Mr. Darnley! at laſt I am compell'd to tell you, he is your enemy and mine—it is that very friend, who would deſtroy your domeſtic peace; who would rob you of a heart, that is, and ever ſhall be all your own! and that, even now, might have triumph'd o'er a helpleſs woman, had not his friendly arm been ſtretch'd to ſerve me.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: It's true—I'll ſwear it!—I'll— (another book falls.) crau—au—au!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I'll not believe it—he is above ſuch arts, and I would have you, madam, not encreaſe your guilt, by daring to abuſe my beſt of friends.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Beſt of friends!—upon my ſoul▪ you've a rare ſet of acquaintance then.—Sir! I always had a knack at ſpeaking what comes uppermoſt, and I ſay, Sir George wanted to turn me out, in order to lock her in—I ſay, he gave me this wound, in trying to defend her from his inſolence—I ſay he is now conceal'd in this room!

div.stage: (Books fall from the Library, and leave an open ſpace. GINGHAM looks round, and ſees Sir GEORGE'S face frowning at him through the aperture.)

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No—I don't ſay he is in the room—I don't! becauſe—becauſe— (looking round again) its better to be choak'd then kill'd.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: See how he prevaricates: and therefore, that my friend may be ſlander'd and I deceiv'd no longer, 'tis time I ſhould decide—Maria!—It almoſt kills me to pronounce it— (aſide) we meet no more—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Stay—ſpare me but a moment—I cannot—will not loſe him; Harry, think of our love—our children. —

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Sir! ſir!—let me aſk you two queſtions— (Another book falls, and Sir George frowns at him.) Ay, grin away you—Sir! can you ſence, and will you fight?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Perhaps, you'll find, I can, ſir.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: And if I prove that Sir George hid himſelf to avoid you, will you ſtand by, and ſee a poor fellow cut to atoms?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No—on the contrary, I ſhall be ſo convinc'd of the truth of your ſtory —

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Say you ſo? then come out you black infernal ſeducer!

div.stage: (Runs up to the Library—forces open the front doors, and amidſt the falling of all the books, Sir GEORGE GAUNTLET is diſcover'd!)

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: There—there he is! and now come on, if you dare—here's a pair of the beſt fencers in Europe?
sp.stage: (Snatching up a ſword and placing himſelf by Darnley.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: 'Tis all unravel'd—deteſted hypocrite!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Ah, Darnley!—how d'ye do!—this is a droll circumſtance, isn't it!—but I hope you are convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I am convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: We're all convinc'd, ſir.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: That you and Lady Sarah have join'd in a conſpiracy to deceive me and betray my wife; that you have meanly put on the maſk of friendſhip, to conceal the blackeſt artifices, and that if you had come to my houſe and boldly plunder'd me of all my fortune—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: He'd only have been hang'd!—but now he ſhall be cut to atoms.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Be cautious in your language, Mr. Darnley—you know my diſpoſition.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
I do—I know you well: and henceforth if you dare, either by action, word, or look; mark me, ſir—raiſe but a bluſh in her unſullied
cheek, I will reſent it—I'll inflict a puniſhment, great as your arrogance deſerves!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Arrogance!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ay, arrogance!—are you deaf!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Sir, this requires an explanation; you ſhall hear from me.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Pooh!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Delay not then, for I ſhall leave your houſe this moment, (Sir George exit.)—come Maria—to you and this gentleman I have a thouſand apologies—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Bleſs you! I'm amply paid in letting my tongue wag—and as to any thing elſe, allow me once more to ſpeak my mind to your ſweet couſin, Clara! come let's go to her—Oh! you well bred ruffian!—to be firſt pink'd, and then nearly choak'd by ſuch a —; on the whole, though, I never fought better in all my life!

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE I.—A Room in a Tavern—Dinner under Covers—Darnley diſcover'd ſitting at the Table— Waiter attending.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Tell Sir George Gauntlet, Mr. Darnley is waiting—what's o'clock?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Six, ſir.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: The time draws near—I wonder where my friend can be? put ſome wine on the table and leave me.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Sir George is below, in cloſe converſation with a gentleman, who ſeems anxious to ſee you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: His ſecond, I ſuppoſe—tell him, I am here— (Waiter exit.) 'Sdeath!—to what have I reduc'd myſelf?—I that had every joy this world can give—a peaceful home—a wife that lov'd, and children that rever'd me!—I to be now in a tavern, on the eve of meeting with a profeſs'd duelliſt? to be about to commit murder, or elſe to live diſhonour'd and diſgrac'd—Oh, Maria!—when thou ſhalt hear thy huſband is no more, wilt thou forgive me?—wilt thou— but my fate determines hers, and if I fall ſhe is for ever loſt!

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: The gentleman from Sir George Gauntlet, ſir.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Admit him—now then for the event!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I'm ſo fag'd—ſo completely knock'd up (ſees the dinner.) ha, ha! what's here?—the very thing to revive me.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I hope, ſir, you haven't been talking to Sir George.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Yes, but I have though—you employ'd me as ſecond, and if you're ſhot, it ſhall be in the way I like beſt. (ſitting down) Waiter! waiter!

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.stage: (To Gingham, who is going to pull off a cover of one of the diſhes.)
sp.p: Sir! ſir!—Sir George order'd that diſh not to be touch'd till he came.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Did he?—then it's the pick'd thing I ſuppoſe, ſo I'll eat it all up directly, (uncovers it, and ſees a brace of piſtols laying 'midſt powder and ball.) here—it's quite at his ſervice, and I wiſh the whole were in his ſtomach with all my ſoul!— (giving the diſh to the waiter, and uncovering another.) Ah! here's ſomething that I can ſwallow. (begins eating.) Well after hunting every where for Sir George, I found him below ſtairs at laſt—"ſo" ſays I "my little Librarian"—alluding to the book-caſe you know—"when are you and this jealous huſband"—alluding to you, you know—"to fight this fooliſh duel?" (drinks a glaſs of wine.) Clara! my dear Clara Sedley!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Well, ſir.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Says I "the fact is this; one will be kill'd, the other be hang'd, and the world get rid of two hot-headed fellows:" ſays he, "Will
Darnley make me an apology?" ſays I "he might as well."

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: You did not!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ah, but I did though "it's very well for faſhionable huſbands, to leave their wives with friends, in hopes of getting divorces and damages; but what right," ſays I, "has a country ſquire to quit his farm, and truſt his wife, with baronets, fools, and coxcombs?— to plant his own horns" ſays I! (drinks.) "Succeſs to trade."

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: And how did this end, ſir?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: How!—why the other ſecond interfer'd—ſaid Sir George could'nt fire at you, and adviſed him to apologize—he heſitated— I put my hand on my ſword—reminded him of my fine fencing—he ſign'd this paper—I've already ſhewn it to Mrs. Darnley, and ſo— (drinks) Here's the child that has two fathers!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: 'Tis ample, final ſatisfaction—wasn't my Maria happy?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: She was—but with women, grief ſoon follows joy, you know—ſhe ſays, your uncle, whoever he is, has order'd you to quit Bath, and go abroad—that ſhe is to be left behind, and as your fortune is exhauſted, ſhe fears you muſt conſent—I'm ſorry I'm pinch'd too—however— (drinks.) Here's confuſion to your ſtingy old uncle!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Unfeeling! perſecuting man!—ſeparate me from all I love—I know the motive for this barbarous conduct—he has found a ſon, on whom he means to laviſh all his favours, and while he rolls in luxury, I and my family may ſtarve —may—but he comes.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: So Mr. Darnley: how dare you intrude into the houſes of great people, and thus repeatedly diſgrace me?—look'ye, ſir—I have made up my mind—you muſt ſeek your fortune abroad—I'll pay your expences to the continent, and leſt your family ſhould be a burthen to you, I'll provide for your wife at home.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Oh, ſir! do not part us!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I will!—I'm reſolv'd! (ſeeing Gingham.) hah!—what do I ſee?—my boy!—my darling!—how came you here you rogue?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Father, you're come in time—juſt in time to finiſh the bottle! (filling him a humper, and putting it in his hand) drink! drink the laſt toaſt!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, what is it?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: "Confuſion to Darnley's"—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: With all my heart—"confuſion to Darnley's"—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: "Stingy old uncle!"

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Stingy old uncle!—why that's confuſion to myſelf you dog!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: What! is it you—well! hang me if I didn't think it was my father—that is my other father, the money-lender—couſin—relation—how are you!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nonſenſe! never mind him—I've brought you your commiſſion—a company in a regiment ſerving in Ireland.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Have you! (to Sir Paul.) who'd have thought my father was your miſerly uncle, heh!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: It's three hundred a-year, my boy! pſha! don't mind him I tell you, (pulling him away from Darnley.) I reſerve every thing for you—I always meant to give all I could to my ſon.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Did you!—Oh then it comes to the ſame point; why, perhaps, you'll give me two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, that I will.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: What! and the commiſſion too!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes, and the commiſſion too! here they are both—and ſome ten years hence, I'll join the regiment, and ſerve under you; under my brave ſon!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No—under your brave nephew if you like—I don't underſtand the exerciſe, and Darnley does! and therefore, as we're all relations—all in a family, I'll e'en give him the commiſſion—Nay, don't be ſhy couſin—it makes no difference father, does it?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Death and fire! it does, ſir, it makes all the difference, and I ſwear—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Softly—you can make me a hero in another way—as I was brought up to trade, pop me into the train bands—then I can be kill'd in the artillery ground in one day, and be alive in the ſhop the next! ſo keep the commiſſion, couſin; keep it— (Forcing it into Darnley's hand.) and here—here's the money to take you, your wife and children to Ireland— (giving the bank notes.—there! now moderate your joy, father! you've done a kind, generous action to be ſure: but why! why in ſuch an ecſtacy!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ecſtacy! agony you puppy!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Gently, gently, at the public breakfaſt I ſhall ſound forth your praiſes—come,
couſin—the beſt of the joke is, I've another father; and though he wont lend you a ſhilling, I'll make him ſend you linen enough to ſhirt your whole regiment.—Farewell, thou liberal man!— look!—Self-gratification has brought tears of joy into his eyes!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Tears of joy!—if being cheated out of my money, makes me cry for pleaſure, what ſhall I do, if I get it back again?—was there ever ſuch a fellow?—however the commiſſion is of no uſe to Darnley—but then the two hundred pounds—and the eaſe with which he did it.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A letter from your Ward, Sir Paul. It requires an immediate anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.q: Sir, I am now at the Public Breakfaſt, where Miſs Savage actually inſiſted on my coming. I have diſcovered a deep plot of Mr. Savage's, and when I tell you, I am in danger of being run away with, without my conſent, I'm ſure you will fly to the relief of your—Affectionate Ward, CLARA SEDLEY.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I'll come directly— (Servant exit.)— So—So—they have heard of her ſudden acquiſition of fortune—of the Copper Mines being diſcovered on her eſtate, and now like true ſavages, they mean to paw the property—but I've a huſband for her in my eye. She has formed an affection for this liberal ſon of mine, and the dog can't take her for a man in woman's cloathes.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: You knave!—if I catch you—how! has he left the tavern!—Ah! Sir Paul!—pray Sir, have you ſeen any thing of my ſon?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I know nothing of your ſon, ſir.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: He has been diſtributing my property— giving away my money, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: 'Gad! My ſon has been doing me the ſame favour.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Ay, ſir; but my ſon has ſwindled me out of two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: That's the exact ſum!—my ſon has ſwindled me out of—ſo let's ſhake hands and cry for joy!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Well, well—I can afford it—but, Sir Paul, there is only one way he can make me retribution—you've heard of our ward's copper mines, and though you have only known me as a private gentleman, and I you as joint guardian—yet I think you will conſent to her marrying the man I propoſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: And pray, who may the gentleman be?—not the Honourable Mr. Savage, I hope, for he has no property, but my two racers.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: No—no—my Son!—my rogue of a Son!—will you agree?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why I would with pleaſure only—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: What Brother Guardian?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I mean to propoſe my rogue of a ſon.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Your ſon!—why how came you by a ſon?—but to the point—my boy has won her heart, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: So has mine too, Mr. Fluſh.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Yours too!—Sdeath, Sir Paul—this racing has turned your brain.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Racing!—Iv'e done with it, ſir— I hate it—I'm above the turf now.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Above the turf!—I wiſh you were under it!—do you pretend ſhe loves both our ſons?—two men at the ſame time, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: To be ſure—ſhe's not the firſt woman that has lov'd twenty at the ſame time, ſir— but as ſhe can't marry without our joint conſent, and is now in great diſtreſs at Lady Sarah Savage's public breakfaſt, let's adjourn there directly.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: With all my heart—I can afford it— Publick breakfaſt!—why this is later than uſual— (Looking at his Watch)—Nine o'clock at night!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ah, theſe are late hours: but what need we care, Mr. Fluſh?—we that have health, youth, ſpirits—do you know there is only one houſe in England that affects my conſtitution?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: And what houſe is that?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I never was there but twice—the firſt time there was a motion about relieving poor inſolvent debtors, and the houſe was ſo empty I got an ague. The next time, ſomebody mov'd to remove the hackney coaches from Bond-Street, and the benches were ſo cram'd that I was thrown into a ſever!—So hey for the breakfaſt.—Youth's the ſeaſon made for joy!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Love is then our duty! &c.

div.head: SCENE II.—A garden at Mr. Savage's on Lanſaown hill—a marquee at the upper wing, in which is ſeen a table full of fruits, wine, meat, tea urns, coffee pots, &c. A diſtant view of Bath—moon riſing.—Long flouriſh of clarinets!
div.stage: Enter Lady SARAH SAVAGE and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Call Miſs Clara— (Servant enters marquee.)—I have given this party in order to ſecure this young creature and her fortune, for my brutiſh brother has ſo leſſen'd our gold, that only her copper can ſave us from ſinking—if her guardians refuſe, we are prepar'd for bolder ſchemes.
Enter CLARA. Well: my dear girl, how do you like our breakfaſt? —breakfaſt by moonlight? isn't it quite charming—ſo nouvêlle?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Quite—and in addition to tea and coffee, here are fowls, fruit, and wine, ſo that you may breakfaſt, dine, drink tea, and ſup all in the ſame meal—nouvêlle!—ſurely nobody elſe is ſo ſingular.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: I don't know—I never copy—the world's ſo very ignorant—that only act unlike other people, and you're pretty ſure of being right, but, didn't you like the muſic—the ſinging?—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No; I don't much like theſe ſine ſingers —it's a long time before you prevail on them to ſing, and then when they once begin—faith! they never ſtop. I declare I only ſaw one perſon I liked amongſt the party.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: And who was that?—the dear Signor!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No—the dear creature, my guardian's ſon.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: What! that monſter? I wonder who invited ſuch a heterogeneous animal, and you to prefer him—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Even to your brother, Ma'am—I know Mr. Savage deſigns me his hand; but, if my guardians will agree—and why they leave me in this ſcene of danger when I wrote to Sir Paul—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Here they are both—I'll go call my brother, and by the time I return, I hope I ſhall call you ſiſter—adieu!—Gingham, indeed!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Here ſhe is—here's the girl to anſwer for herſelf—now be cool, Sir Paul—compoſe yourſelf, and I'll fairly put the queſtion to her. Clara, haven't you fix'd your affections?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: To confeſs the truth, I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Very well—ſoftly, Sir Paul! and now, what is the Gentleman's name?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, what is his name, Clary?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Gingham, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: There! I told you ſo—it's my ſon!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why there! I told you ſo—it's my ſon!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Your ſon!—In the firſt place I don't believe you have a ſon; and in the next, do you pretend that this Gingham—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Is my boy! my own darling child!— and I'll prove it.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Well, well, if this is the caſe. I'll make you a fair propoſition, let's call in both our ſons, and let the one ſhe prefers be her huſband.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Agreed—and I'll bet you a hundred pounds ſhe chuſes mine.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Done,—I'll bet you a hundred ſhe chuſes mine.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: My life! my love! my Clara!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Here he comes!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Here he comes

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I cannot live a moment from thee—I—

div.stage: GINGHAM enters from the Marquee, and, ſeeing his two fathers together, pauſes and ſtarts.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Now, Clara—Silence, Sir Paul!—don't you chuſe him!—him!—for your huſband?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Huzza! I've won my bet!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Here is a father don't know his own child.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: And here's a child don't know his own father! upon my ſoul, Gentlemen, I cannot tell which of you had the honour of inventing me; but here I am, and if you have more property to diſtribute—if either of you has another two hundred pounds, I'll diſpoſe of it ſo nearly, that tears of joy ſhall trickle down your cheeks!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.stage: (After looking ſome time at Sir Paul.)
sp.p: Sir Paul!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Mr. Fluſh—We were joint guardians juſt now and—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: And now we're joint fathers it ſeems.—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: This muſt be the tradeſman—a word in private, if you pleaſe, Sir. (They enter the Marquee.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Lay your heads together; ſettle it as you pleaſe; for while Clara ſmiles on me, I care not whether I'm ſon to a haberdaſher, or heir to the grand Turk.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.p: I hope they won't quarrel—I fear Mr. Fluſh will inſiſt—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: He inſiſt!—bleſs you, he'd ſell me for half a crown.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: He's mine! he's mine! the father knows his own child at laſt.—I never ſuſpected Fluſh was clerk to a Lottery Office, and conſequently little thought he was the tradeſman who married my Nelly—'gad! I always took him for a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Did you?—that was very good natur'd of you—and ſo you give me up, Mr. Fluſh?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Yes, I can afford it.—The Tunbridge ſtory is perfectly explain'd, and I have done with you, you rogue—Your wiſe father here has promis'd to reſtore my papers, ſo now you may ſpeak truth till you're black in the face.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: May I? —then I won't; leſt other faces ſhould be of the ſame complexion—but, gentlemen, ſince you've found out who I belong to, will you inform me who this lady is to belong to?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Fluſh—I'm ſure I ſhall have your conſent—you are a monied man and have lived with people of rank.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Your pardon, ma'am, if I had lived with people of rank, I had not been a monied man—the fact is, I touch caſh wherever I can, and Sir Paul has brib'd me ſo handſomely, that I have ſold my conſent—I have ſold my ward as well as my ſon, and for this plain reaſon—I can afford it.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Clary, take his hand, my Girl. (Giving her to Gingham.) The dog has an odd way of ſpeaking his mind, but inſtead of checking him, encourage him; many a man only wants to be told of his errors to correct them, and that is my caſe—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Your caſe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes, my boy—ſince you talked of ſelf-gratification bringing tears of pleaſure into my eyes, I reſolv'd to try the experiment—I determin'd to retrench my expences, to ſell my hounds, diſpoſe of my ſtud, and ſee if I could not lay out my money on rational and ſolid pleaſures; in beſtowing happineſs on two as innocent and injur'd creatures as ever exiſted!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Niece, your hand—Darnley forgive what's paſt, and henceforth if I don't prove a friend to you, tell that ſon of mine to ſpeak his mind to me—tell him to take another two hundred pounds out of my pocket; nay, diſperſe my whole property—any thing, ſo you don't drink "Confuſion to a ſtingy old uncle!"

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Sir, we owe every thing to your ſon—he has been our pilot through the ſtorms of faſhion, and if he now ſecures to us independence and our cottage—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Independence and a cottage! S'life! you ſhall have affluence and a farm as large as Saliſbury Plain—I'll come and ſee you every ſummer! ay! for ſixty years to come!—odsheart! they ſay I'm like an old Volcano burnt out! but it's a miſtake—I'm like an Egyptian lamp that flames for ever!—A'nt I, my boy?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Muſt I ſpeak truth, father?—mum!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: You have made me the happieſt of men, Sir Paul; but you muſt excuſe me when I ſay, that your ſon has the firſt and greateſt claim—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Nay, Couſin; if you knew me half as well as I know myſelf, you would find I have as many faults as any of you.—But come, let's adjourn from this vulgar faſhionable ſcene, and while they drink one toaſt, we'll give another—

q.l: The charms that conſtitute each female grace.
To man, be bold and daring ſchemes confin'd,
Woman for ſofter paſſions was deſign'd,
And by meek virtue—to ſubdue mankind!
